editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PRETENDERS: OR, The Town Unmaskt. A COMEDY. Acted at the Theatre in Little Lincolns-Inn-Fields. By His Majeſty's Servants.
div.q: Ficta Voluptatis Cauſa ſint proxima veris.
div.p: LONDON, Printed for Peter Buck, at the ſign of the Temple, near the Inner-Temple-Gate in Fleet-ſtreet, 1698.

☞Newly publiſhed the two laſt new Tragedies, viz. Caligula Emperour of Rome, by Mr Crown. Falſe Diſcovery, or Love in Ruins, a Tragedy; with a Preface in anſwer to Mr Dryden's Copy of Verſes, prefixed to a Comedy, called Heroick Love.

div.head: TO THOMAS BARNARDISTON, Eſq OF Ketton in Suffolk.
div.p: AFter a Poet has made his appearance upon the Stage, the next thing he generally does, is to take his ſtation in ſome great man's Anti-chamber; there to ſcrew himſelf into a protection for his Play, with a Paper ſtufft full of Bombaſt-encomiums of his new Patrons high Merits and wonderful Qualifications: Which perhaps, till that time, were as little heard of in the world, as the Poet was known to his thus applauded Maecenas.

The buſineſs of this Dedication to you, Sir, is quite otherwiſe; for as I have the honour to be very well known to You, ſo I take this opportunity, as well to expreſs the ſentiments of my eſteem for You, as to publiſh my thanks for paſt Obligations. A poor Tribute indeed! But as 'tis my preſent All, ſo it's wholly at your ſervice.

And now, while I am paying my Addreſſes to a Barnardiſton, methinks I have as copious a ſubject to enlarge upon as I cou'd wiſh. But leſt▪ I ſhou'd ſeem to incur the reflection I have thought fit to make on others, I ſhall only hint at what I cou'd not poſſibly omit. I ſhou'd exaſperate the Country You live in, ſhou'd I not take notice with what a due regard they have all ſixt their Eyes upon You. Nor is there any queſtion to be made, but that in this their well-grounded hopes, You will even out-do their Expectations. And tho Lincolnſhire as well as Suffolk claims an Intereſt in You, yet the latter has that to ſay of your Family, which can ſcarce be parallell'd in any other.

That Ketton ſhou'd have been the continued Manſion-houſe of ſeven and twenty Sir Thomas Barnardiſtons, ſucceſſively from Father to Son, with but the interruption of one Sir Nathaniel, Your great Grandfather, is a thing highly remarkable. And ſince the Honour of Baronet is but of late date in the world, no doubt but that badge of Knighthood was ſtill conferr'd upon theſe brave Anceſtors of Yours for their fidelity to the Crown▪ and as a reward for the ſervices they ſeverally afforded their reſpective Princes. This noble train of Sir Thomas's is at preſent clos'd with the now Sir Thomas Barnardiſton, your truly honourable Father, a perſon every way ſo conſpicuous, that he has no occaſion for the leaſt touch of a Poet's varniſh, to gloſs over his true and real worth. All that I ſhall ſay upon this account is, that being ſo
well acquainted with that tender Union and Correſpondence that is betwixt you, I may ſafely anſwer for your joyning with me in an O Ʋtinam ſero in Coelum Redeat! After this may your Lineage run the length of time; and may Ketton never want a Barnardiſton for its Proprietor, till the world wants a Mortal for its Inhabitant.

Thus, Sir, as I began my Epiſtle in a method ſomething uncuſtomary for one of my profeſſion; and having all along forborn to harangue you with fulſome Flattery, ſo I ſhall beg leave to conclude without ſo much as ſide glancing a ſingle Compliment upon my ſelf, and let me tell you, that's a great piece of ſelf-denyal in a Poet of this Age. I am confident, that as you wou'd be apt to ſcorn me for the one, ſo you'd laugh at me for the other. If I can find out any value to put upon my ſelf, 'tis not in reſpect of my performances, but for the good fortune I have to be,
div.closer: SIR, Your moſt Obedient, and moſt obliged Servant, Tho. Dilke.

list.head: MEN
list.item: Lord Courtipoll. A vain empty-skull'd Lord, pretending himſelf to be highly intereſted at Court, and conſulted in all State-affairs. A keeping Gallant to Mrs. Minx. Mr. Thurmond.
Sir Wealthy Plainder, A Rich cloſe Curmugeon, pretending to be wholly decay'd in his Fortunes. A private Cully to Mrs. Minx. Mr. Underhill.
Sir Bellamour Blunt, A plain downright Speaker. A Country Gentleman, of good ſenſe and knowledge. In love with Ophelia. Mr. Kynaſton.
Vainthroat, A looſe talkative Gentleman of the Town. Mr. Bowman
Broakage, A poor Bankrupt Merchant, pretending himſelf to be very rich. A pretender to the Widow. Mr. Trefuſe.
Captain Bownceby, A bluſtring caſheer'd Subaltern Officer, pretending himſelf a Captain. Another pretender to the Widow. Mr. Bright.
Nickycrack, A ſly knaviſh fellow, who pretends to all the honeſty imaginable. Mr. Bowen.
Prim, Lord Courtipoll's Valet de Chambre, a poor Scoundrel, but pretending himſelf to be of a Gentlemans Family. Mr. Baily.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Widow Thoroſhift, Left low in the World, but ſetting up for a vaſt Fortune, Mrs. More.
Minx, Her Siſter, a cunning intreaguing Coquet, who pretends to have been bred altogether in the Country. Kept by Lord Courtipoll. Mrs. Peryng.
Ophelia, Daughter to Sir Wealthy Plainder; a virtuous young Lady, privately in love with Sir Bellamour Blunt. Mrs. Bowman.
Sweetny, Siſter to Nickycrack: a Boarding Landlady. A fawning diſſembling Hypocrite, pretending to much Piety and Devotion. Mrs. Lee.
Nibs, A Servant-maid in the Family. A cunning tattling wench, but a great pretender to ſecreſie. Mrs. Lawſon.
Doll, Servant to Minx; of the ſame pretention as her Miſtreſs. Mrs. Willis.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.stage: Spoken By Mr. Bowen, coming upon the Stage in a great huff, follow'd by a Prompter, with a Paper in his hand; and by a Boy with a Bottle and Glaſs.
div.l: I Won't ſpeak this Prologue—Go tell him ſo;
If he no Wit, I can ſome Manners ſh • w.
I curſe the Criticks! Rail at Men of Senſe;
Gadzooks I wonder at his impudence.
Beſides—
He ſhou'd have choſe ſome tender Cherub face,
Whoſe melting ſmiles cou'd ſo bewitch the place,
That might have forc'd him to a ſtate of Grace.
Such a queer Phiz as mine, on my Salvation,
Will ne • re retrieve him from his late Damnation.
And yet methinks, I'm loath to loſe him quite,
Firſt let me drink, then try to do him right.
Here you Gall'ry Spankers: a Health to thoſe
That value Brawn, and ſcorn the Lath-backt Beaus.
Thoſe City Ladies who to quench a flame,
From their own Counters ſpring the luſty game.
Next to all ſound Masks. Yup Kecks not one drop will down,
This plainly ſhews there's none in all the Town.
Come a Bumper to th'Pit—No doubt but you
Expect from me, a Health entirely new.
Your thoughts I wou'd not willingly foreſtal;
If this Play's damn'd, Confuſion to ye all.
div.stage: Fills again. To the ſide boxes
div.l: Sirrah, be ſure you fill me nicely now,
While I on either ſide profoundly bow.
Gad, ſure to Men of ſo much Grace and Feature,
There ſhould be left a ſpice of Human Nature.
Then let your Goodneſs more conſpicuous be,
And don't you ſnuff at every fault you ſee.
So may your Miſtreſſes be over kind,
And none of all your Imperfections find.
Till thus you ſtand, full of your ſelves poſſeſt,
But leave good drudging Sparks to do the reſt.
Now on my Knees, I'll veneration pay,
And heartily Drink, (Drinks.) To what I durſt not ſay.
In ſhort, Ladies—
Thus does our Poet for your mercy ſue,
And ſwears he dreads no other Stars but you.

div.head: THE PRETENDERS: OR, The Town Unmaskt.
ACT I. Scene Convent-Garden Piazza's.
div.stage: Sir Bellamour Blunt and Vainthroat, in Riding habits, as juſt come to Town.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: WEll, Sir Bellamour, how ſhall we diſpoſe of our ſelves, now we are arriv'd at this glorious Town of London?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Why faith, Vainthroat, I'm not well acquainted with the Town; but by what I do know, thou mayſt e'n chooſe what corner of it thou thinkſt fit, and yet never want objects for either Ridicule or Detraction; and thoſe are thy two darling faculties.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, why ſhou'd you ſay that of me, who am the niceſt man living of all peoples Reputations?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Reputation! I'd undertake there wou'd not be a ſingle grain of ſuch a thing in the Univerſe, were it in the power of thy Tongue to blaſt it.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Come, Sir Bellamour, I muſt tell you, that you have got a damn'd unbecoming quality, to ſpeak always what you think, 'tis the abſurdeſt thing that a Gentleman of this age can be guilty of.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Would it not be more abſurd, either to ſpeak without thinking, or impudently to belye a man's own opinion?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Not at all I vow; I find you are, as you ſay your ſelf, not well acquainted with the Town: why all Gentlemen of good aſſurance and right Town breeding, firſt never think of what they ſay, and then don't care one • a • thing whether a ſyllable of it be truth or not.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: For that reaſon I'll avoid all Town Company, to prevent being ſhockt with the inſolence of Lies, or ſtunn'd with the eternal ſputter of Nonſence.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: At the preſent we'll wave diſputes—Let's ſettle our ſelves into convenient Lodgings, get ſplendid Equipages; and then Beau it about the Town.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: VVhat the Devil doſt mean by that fooliſh word, Beau?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: VVhy faith the title and qualifications of a Beau, have long been the ſtanding mark for the random ſhot of all the Poets of the Age. And to very little purpoſe.—The Beaus bravely ſtand their ground ſtill e'gad—The truth on't is, they are a ſort of caſe-harden'd animals, as uncapable of Scandal, as they are inſenſible of any impreſſion either from Satyr or good Senſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: And prithee how muſt theſe caſe-harden'd animals be diſtinguiſht?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Barring Reflection, I believe the beſt way to be adquainted with the whole Tribe of 'em, wou'd be to get a general Regiſter drawn from all the Perſumers Shop-books in town—Or which is more ſcandalous, to examine the Chaulks in all the Chair-mens Cellars about the Pallmall; where each morning the poor fellows ſit, looking penſively upon their long ſcores, ſhaking their heads and ſaying—Ah! how many times have we trotted with ſuch a powder'd Son of a nine Fathers, from the Chocolate-houſe to the Play, and never yet ſaw a groat of his Money.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mr Vainthroat you are welcome to Town, you are the only perſon living that I moſt wanted a ſight on; I vow and proteſt you are, upon my honeſty.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I never yet heard a man call his honeſty to witneſs, but he prov'd a damn'd Rogue at bottom.—This fellow has Raſcal ſtampt upon his very countenance.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Honeſt Nickycrack, thou art come very opportunely—You may at preſent be aſſiſting to us.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O Lord, in whatever lies in my power, you know, Sir, that you may aſſure your ſelf of me—Is this your friend, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir Bellamour Blunt, Sir: a perſon highly worth your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p:
Sir Bellamour Blunt, I am yours, with all the integrity, ſincerity,
and uprightneſs an honeſt heart is capable of containing—Pray, Sir, how can I be moſt ſerviceable to ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: By going about your buſineſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: You muſt pardon this Gentleman's abrupt ſpeaking, 'tis his way Mr Nickycrack.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Then the Gentleman's way of ſpeaking ſuits punctually with my way of acting, which is always honeſt and downright.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Were I to gueſs at your actions by your looks, I'd ſooner cut out my Tongue, than ſpeak a ſyllable that ſhould correſpond even with your bare conceptions.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Fie, Sir Bellamour, prithee leave this ſtrange moroſeneſs.—Come honeſt Nickycrack, can'ſt thee adviſe us to any good Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O dear, Sir, my Siſter Sweetny here juſt by, has the beſt conveniency of Lodging and Boarding of any woman in Town—And ſhe, you know, Sir, is a good woman; a woman, tho I ſay it, of much true Piety and Devotion.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I'll hold my life on't, ſhe's a Bawd by her Character.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Why ſuppoſe ſhe were, does not a perſon of that neceſſary function deſerve a more tender expreſſion—As that ſuch a Lady is a moſt obliging officious Virginity-Broaker, Dem me if ſhe ben't the charitableſt creature in the Kingdom—Whenever ye deſign to villi • y, you muſt be ſure to let it be tout en Ridicule, ah, ha, ha. And thus you may modiſhly be allow'd to to beſpatter any body.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I'd as ſoon diſguiſe my perſon to be a baſe and barbarous Aſſaſſin, as I would my thoughts by telling a Lye.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Prithee what Company is there at your Siſter's at preſent?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, we are never without good Company; there's the fine Widow Thoroſhift, a vaſt fortune; and her pretty Country bred innocent Maiden Siſter, Mrs. Minx.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Very well, I know 'em.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And juſt now Sir Wealthy Plainder and his beautiful Daughter Ophelia, have made an addition to the Family.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Sir Wealthy Plainder, and his Daughter Ophelia! Do you hear, Sir Bellamour; the very perſons we came up to Town withal. I am confident you need no farther inducement.—Go Nickycrack, get our Rooms ready, and we'll order our things thither, and follow immediately.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sir I ſhall be proud of obeying your Command.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Ha! My Dear, have I found thee? I have been upon the hunt for ye, with greater vigour than ever I yet purſu'd an Enemy; and that
you may imagin was never with any ſmall heat.—Come faith you muſt aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: In what, good Captain Bownceby? What is the mighty buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: VVhy the mighty buſineſs is love—And who the Devil would think a man of my rough temper, a Soul of that fierceneſs as mine is, ſhould e're be flexible to the beck of a little, puny, blind brat?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Good Captain, the Object?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Object of my uncontroulable paſſion, is the VVidow Thoroſhift: I know you have an intereſt in her—And let me periſh if it ſhan't be worth thy while.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ha! Pimp for a Soldier in time of Peace, ah that's damn'd cool work e'faith.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pox! I underſtand ye.—You ſhan't want your encouragement, tho I ſink my Arrears three parts in four for you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Captain, I have buſineſs at preſent: but aſſure your ſelf you may command me in any thing, ſo your intentions be juſt and honourable; for all the world knows that Mr. Nickycrack will not act otherwiſe than what is becoming an honeſt man.; and as ſuch, I am noble Captain Bownceby's very humble Servant.—Oh! Yonder's Nibs, the truſty Servant-maid, walking this way, ſhe can better inform you in your preſent concerns.—I am yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Nibs, I'll be ſhort and Soldier-like with you. Know then that the ſuze of my Vitals is fired by the lighted Match of your Miſtreſſes Beauty; and if it be not quickly extinguiſht by her cooling P • mp of Pity, dry up my blood, if I ſhan't be blown into the air; and there burſt into millions of fiery atoms.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Sir, I'll endeavour to anſwer you as a Captain ought to be anſwered: I'll ſay but little, but what I do ſay ſhall be to the purpoſe. I ſay, that a Servant that is entruſted with the concerns of a Family, ought always to have Diſcretion ſtand Centinel upon her lips, there ſtrictly to guard the port of her utterance. For my part, I ſcorn to let my tongue, Weather-cock like, wag with the breath of every impertinent enquirer: If I ſee with one eye; I wink with the other: and whatever I hear, is that very moment barricado'd within the precincts of this Breaſt: and mum's the word; and tho I ſay it, that ſhou'd not ſay it, and all that—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay prithee Nibs, halt, halt, halt I ſay.—Come, let's to the purpoſe, I • expect very ſoon to be a Collonel, and I'll give you my parole of honour to make that man a Captain that you ſhall think fit to make your Husband, deal but ſincerely with me, and let me know how things ſtand?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Well Sir, what is't you wou'd know?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why I wou'd know who pays Court to the Widow?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: O Lord! all the world: Who pays Court to a rich Widow? Why Courtiers without Eſtates, Country-Gentlemen damnably in debt, unbenefic'd Divines. Officers without Poſts, Doctors without Patients, Lawyers without Clients, Tradeſmen without Stocks, younger Brothers without either Fortunes or Employs, Beaux upon their laſt legs, caſt Stallions, and begga • ly Poets; and there's the greateſt part of the world, I'm confident on't.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Blood and Brimſtone, Nibs, prithee leave this eternal chattering, and tell me who is my moſt dangerous Rival.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, as I hope to be a Captains Lady, for once I will divulge—There's one Mr. Broakage, a wealthy Merchant, who attacks her vigorouſly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hell and furies! Bombs and Bilboa Blades! May rank Coward be imprinted on this dreadful Countenance, if I don't go raiſe the Siege inſtantly—How! A City-drone ſtand in competition with a daring war-like Hornet? Ha!

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: He's wonderful rich; and you know that's a prevailing accompliſhment in the buſineſs of Love—He has Colonies in all our P • antations, Cargoes in all our Trading bottoms, and Shares in all our Banks.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha! I'll go this moment and depopulate all his Plantations, ſink all his Ships, and blow up all his Banks.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Oh brave Captain!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll Carbonade the Dog full of ghaſtly Wounds, then with my charming Widow in my arms, I'll mount my triumphal Chariot, and drag his mangled Carkaſs around the utmoſt limits of the Univerſe.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Well ſaid Captain!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll firſt go to the Widow, and if I find there be occaſion, I'll put this tremendous ſentence of mine in execution the very moment afterwards. Parch my puddings if I don't.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Nibs, what has the Captain deſerted?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: VVhy faith, I have been whetting his Courage, and ſpurring him in his amour with the VVidow—And you know there's no time to be loſt in that buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Gad 'tis true, for if we don't diſpoſe of her in leſs than four and twenty hours, I'm confident the Tallymen will be for diſman • ing of her—And ſhou'd every Bird ſetch her own Feathers, I doubt the poor Widow Thoroſhift would be left as bare as AEſop's Daw—But firſt I'll to the Commiſſaries Office, and make ſome enquiry after this thundering Captain Bownceby.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Pray do Mr Nickycrack, for as times go now there are near as many that take the names of Captain upon 'em, as there are Soldiers in the Kings Army.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Tis true; for a ſtiff cockt-up Hat, cloſe twiſted Peruke, and a tuckt-in Cravat—

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: A brandy pimpled face, impudent look, and a hoarſe voice.—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: A ſcore of new coyn'd Oaths, and half as many drunken Catches—

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: A great braſs hilt Sword, and an Oaken Plant with a dirty Ribbon in it—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: A blue pair of Breeches and red Stockings—

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Are ſufficient to gain any man the title of a Captain, tho perhaps he be but a Bayliffs Follower—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Or the ſcoundrel Bully to a Widows Coffee-Houſe in a blind Alley.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: And indeed there's as much occaſion that you ſhould go to the Change and make ſome enquiry after Mr Broakage, that ſo we may be ready to ſnap at that which proves the beſt bargain.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: That's right again; for 'tis as difficult to gueſs at the ſubſtance of a Merchant by his figure in the world, as 'tis to know the true grief of a young Widow, by the diſmal appearance of her mourning Veil.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Or at the real intentions of a bluſhing Virgin, when ſhe ſets her mouth in print, and ſays No to a good proffer—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Or as it is to know the age of a Beau, without having firſt conſulted the perſon that ſhaves his empty Noddle, or his Operator, to be informed, whether this European Monſter is not obliged to the great African one, for the whiteneſs of his Teeth—

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Or to know his natural imperfections, unleſs his Valet de Chambre be workt to a Confeſſion, what ſuppliments his Beauſhip makes uſe of, to correct the deficiencies of his Shape and Complexion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Right e'gad, as whether his nice jutting backſide be real fleſh and blood, or only an artificial Cuſheon of quilted Cotton—

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Or whether the calves of thoſe pretty Legs he ſtruts upon, do not owe their original to ſome ingenious Artiſts amongſt the Stocking-Weavers in Spittle Fields.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ha! Yonder's the Widow, and my Siſter Sweetny coming this way from their evenings devotion.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: A fine trade indeed, Prayer-Books in their hands, and the World, Fleſh, and the Devil in their hearts.

div.stage: Enter Widow Thoroſhift, Sweetny, with Books in their hands.

sp.speaker: Nick.
Sweet.
sp.p: Pray who are they?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Why there's Mr Vainthroat, a perſon that we all know, and his friend Sir Bellamour Blunt, ſuch a moroſe piece of Knighthood that I never yet ſaw; ſhould he chance to go into your Cellar, he'd endanger ſowring your Beer, more than all the Thunder of a hot Summer—But no matter for that, he's a man of ſubſtance, and that is enough for our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: I have heard of him; but is Mr Vainthroat come to Town? I vow I am glad on't, for he's a pure man.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr Vainthroat indeed is moſt excellent company amongſt the women; he knows all the ſcandalous news about Town, eſpecially that part of it, that is moſt neceſſary for us to know, as when the cloſe-fiſted Steward fills his Maſters Fob for him, and thinks fit to entruſt him with the management of three or four hundred of his own Guineas.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p:
Or when the City Merchant, after a lumping bargain by inch of Candle, comes to laviſh away a hundred pieces amongſt our Bon •
Roba's of Covent Garden.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Or when an Inns-of-Court Spark confeſſes a Statute to raiſe five hundred pounds, upon the reverſion of his Fathers Mannor houſe, to make his laſt flouriſh withal—And when that is fairly ſnackt by Bawds, Pimps, and Strumpets, the vain Coxcomb ſneaks over the Water into the bounds of the Kings Bench, and there dozes away the remainder of his Life, with fulſome Flip, and naſty Mundungus.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, he has always pretty ſtories of the women too.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Ay ſo he has, Madam; and you know 'tis the delight of our Souls to hear others of our own Sex reflected on.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So it is, Mrs Sweetny, A • , ha, ha, I laugh'd heartily when he told me how my Lady Rampabout uſes to infuſe Opium into her Husbands Tea, and when the good old Knight is faſt aſleep in his chair of eaſe by the fire ſide, ſhe very fairly receives her friendly viſits without any danger of a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: And I laugh'd as heartily when he told me of a certain Fleetſtreet Dame, that had got a Receipt to give her Husband the naſty Northern diſtemper, by dreſſing his Shirts with a white Powder, that ſo ſhe might have a pretence to lye alone, and there entertain the careſſes of her luſty long limb'd f • re-man of the Shop.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: But good lack, alack! how came we to enter into this diſcourſe before we had laid our Prayer-books out of our hands?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, come, as long as there is no body but our ſelves, 'tis well well enough.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But pray let's leave this chit chat, and mind the main chance: Madam Thoroſhift you ſhan't fail to have an account of the true eſtimate of your new Lovers.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Mr Nickycrack, I am wonderfully obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: In the firſt place I will go to my Lord Courtipolls, about your Siſter, Madam Minx's concern, by this time I ſuppoſe he may be come from Court: I'll ſecure you, I'll bring him along with me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray do, Sir, and beſure you urge the buſineſs home to his Lordſhip, make him ſenſible of all the incident charges of a lying-in bout.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Nay faith he's not unſenſible of ſuch matters; for I believe his Lordſhip has paid for fifty lying-in bouts, where he has had no farther concern but for the bare credit on't.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The truth on't is, his politick vanity makes him the moſt accompliſht Cully in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I'll undertake there's never a Crack in Town, if ſhe reports that ſhe was firſt debaucht by my Lord Courtipoll, but is ſure to receive a gratuity from his Lordſhip, for telling that moſt obliging lye.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: 'Tis pity indeed, that his mighty buſineſs at Court about State affairs would not allow us more of his company.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: He buſineſs at Court! 'tis all pretences, all pretences • aith, Siſter. 'Tis true, he goes every day thither, but has nothing to do there, but to walk out of one Room into another, which indeed he does with a wouderful deal of politick gravity. And as for his being conſulted in State affairs, I dare ſwear his opinion was never askt, tho it were only to know the qualifications of his neighbour in the Country, who ſollicited hard at Court to be made a Worſhipful Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Well, 'tis time for me to go, and give a welcome to my new gueſts. Madam, will you pleaſe to walk?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Mr. Nickycrack, my Lord has urgent buſineſs with you, and would ſpeak with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mr Prim, I was this moment coming to pay my humble Deveirs to the moſt noble Lord Courtipoll, and now at his Lordſhips command, I'll fly▪ I'll fly to his honourable preſence.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Mrs Nibs, I congratulate the chearful ruddineſs of your Complexion, and muſt own, that I find a freſh ſpring of joy begin to flouriſh in my Boſom, by the warm influence of your bright ſhining Eyes—Gad that was finely ſpoke, and very much like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p:
Pray, M •
Prim, don't exerciſe your Court flattery upon me.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable of flattery, Gad Dem me—May I forfeit the honour of my Family, if I han't a great veneration for you.

sp.speaker: Nib • .
sp.p: Your Family! Pray what Family are you of, Sir?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: What Family? I am of the ancient Family of the Prims of Prim Caſtle, upon Chivet Hills, on the Borders of Scotland; and would have you to know, tho I ſerve a Peer of the Realm, yet I'd ſcorn to ſerve the beſt Commoner in the three Kingdoms. Upon the word of a Gentleman you may believe me.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, I could tell this pitiful ſcoundrel another ſtory if I pleas'd—But that I'll reſerve to another opportunity— [Aſide] Well, Mr Prim, I am ſorry I cannot ſtay at preſent, and pay you the honour that is due to you, and to the ancient Family of the Prims of Prim Castle
〈◊〉 B • t I ſhall leave you in good hands; ſo • I ſee Madam Minx's Maid, honeſt Country Doll, coming this way, and ſo I am worthy Mr Prims moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Mrs Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Miſtreſs Dorothy! pray Miſtreſs me no Miſtreſſes; I am plain Country Doll.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Then ſweet Country Doll, may baſe ignominy taint the blood of me, if you han't ſomething in your face that looks very charming.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Charming! what's charming, I never heard ſuch a word in all my breath, not I.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Pretty Innocence!—why prithee Doll, how do they make love in the Country?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Why in't Country, if John oaſts a Motion to Joan, and Joan ſhe likes it, then Joan gis John't Sillabub, Then John teakes Joan to the Alehouſe, and gis her Plumb Ceake and Ale, where m'aps ater't firſt Flagon, John ſlaps Joan or't face, then Joan ſhe's dugged. But after t'other por or two all is well again; and Joan ſhe promiſes to meet John at night upon Meaſters Hay Mow, where a hun • er't to one but Joan ſhe proves with Chilt. Then Joan ſhe fetches John for't the Juſtice, and Juſtice ater't hearing whole ſtory, makes John marry Joan, and there's an end of tat buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, very pretty I vow.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p:
Now pray Meaſte •
Prim, will yo tell one how yo maken Love in London.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: That I will Doll to the beſt of my power. In the firſt place, Great men make haughty love with their titles and honours—Elder Brothers juſt come to their Eſtates, make taring love, with gaudy Liveries and gilt Coaches—Statesmen and men of buſineſs, make ſolid love with formal ſhrug and politick grimace. And your Citizens make ſordid love, with paultry Preſents from their well-ſtockt Purſes.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Good, pray go on.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Officers of the Army make thundering love, with Vollies of Oaths and Curſes. And the Beaus make as apiſh and impertinent love with their Combs and Snuff boxes, as the Wits do tireſome and whining love, with their Songs and Elegies.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: So, very well.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Your cropt-ear'd Prentices make ſneaking love, with ſtealing into Abigal's pocket either an Orange ſtuft with Cloves, or a good ſlice of Ginger-bread—Pert dapper Pages, and ſpruce Valet de Chambres, make teazing love with ruffling of Heads and hawling of Petticoats. In fine, your Bullies, and Troopers, make barbarous love, by knocking down their Dowdies, and enjoying them in a ſwoond.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: O Gemini gemini, did one ever hear the like on't?—But pray when will yore Lord come and make love again with my Miſtreſs? Poor Soul! he has brought her to a fine paſs a my word; ſhe's either longing or puking all the day long, ſo ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: My pretty Dolly, my Lord won't fail of being with her this evening; and as ſoon as they are Chamber'd, thee and I will go and ſolace our ſelves over a glaſs of Wine at the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Marry but don yo think that I will truſt my ſelf? that would be fine work indeed.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: In token that I'll do nothing but what is becoming a Gentleman, I'll make my dear Ruſtick Cherub a Preſent of this Diamond Ring.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, a Diamond Ring on Doll's Finger, how that will look when I goo a into th' Country, to rake ater't Cart or milk Kye again.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: It was preſented me by a great Courtier, and I hope Doll you will accept of it from my hands, as an inviolable pledge of my juſt and honourable pretenſions.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: In troth Meaſter Prim, it ſhall go hard, but that I'll make you amends ſome way or other—Ods ſo, here comes my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: How now Doll, why are you not at home doing what I bad you?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I was juſt a gooing forſooth.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Nay, now ſtay and go along with me—Mr Prim what does my Lord Cou ••• p • 'l mean, never to ſee a body again.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p:
M • dam Minx, I was coming to acquaint your Ladyſhip that his Lordſhip will be with you immediately. I'll aſſure you Madam, that my Lord languiſhes with impatience, till he h • s once more ſacrificed his bleeding heart at the ſhrine of your moſt illuſtrious beauty—
Gad I ſhall rival my Lord with pure dint of Eloquence.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Sackerfize and Luſters, I don't know what you mean by ſuch words not I, we are not uſed to ſuch gibberiſh in the Country—Pray go tell him that my heart is ready to burſt for him, that I have almoſt cry'd my eyes out, that I'll neither eat, drink, nor ſleep till I have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Madam, upon the unblemiſht fidelity of a Gentleman, I'll punctually deliver your Ladyſhips commands.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Well Doll, haſt thee been playing thy Country part with Prim, ha?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: To a hair e'faith, Madam; the Puppy has juſt given me a Diamond Ring to go with him anon to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Let me ſee it. Upon my Soul'tis right, and 'tis high time for me to look to my hits too, and fix his Lord—This evening in ſpight of fate I'll hook him into ſettlement. What ſignifies his Lordſhips paying for Lodging and Diet, and ſome little naſty Pr • eſents of a Gown and Petticoat once a month or ſo. A muſty Quietus Judge would give me as much as that comes to, beſides the aſſurance of a Legacy of broad Gold, that the old Toaſt had palm'd when he ſat upon the Bench for perverting of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, 'tis true, I know a Lady that has three times as much only for ſcratching the Poll of a Gouty Citizen.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: A woman of pleaſure is worſe than an Indian Slave, that has not a Settlement at her own Command. A Quality Miſtreſs ſhould keep her Coach, a brace of Footmen, and a leaſh of young Gallants at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, be rul'd by me, get the writings drawn, according as my Lord has already given you the particulars. And when you have workt up his paſſion to a glowing pitch, then of a ſudden take upon you to be peeviſhly coy, and don't ſo much as let him ſqueeze your hand, till he has firſt ſqueez'd the Wax.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Don't queſtion Doll, but I'll manage him as a Cull of the firſt head ought to be managed.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Do ſo, Madam.

div.l: Tears mixt with Smiles, won't fail to do the feat;
And Country Minx may prove a London cheat.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE A Room in Mrs. Sweetny's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Plainder, Mrs. Sweetny and Ophelia walking off at ſome diſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir W. P.
sp.p: PRay Landlady Sweetny, let me recommend to your care my Daughter Ophelia there—My Daughter, who I may juſtly ſay is—

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Is! Sir Wealthy Plainder? ſhe is the mirrour of Beauty, the pride of Mankind, the glory of her Sex, and the wonder of the Age; ſhe is—

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Struck with amazing confuſion to be thus flatter'd. Oh how odious a creature is a fawning Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: I'll ſay this for Ophelia, that ſhe's an excellent Huſwife—You muſt know, do you mind, that I have bred her to be—

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: A ſlave to a miſerable parent

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: To be, I ſay, exquiſitively officious in the affairs of the Family. She ſhall clarify Whey, make Nettle Porridge, and Barley-broth, with ever a Girl in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: This indeed is a true bill of fare of our late Country Diet.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Now look ye Mrs Sweetny, if you can find me out ſome ſubſtantial Tradeſman, that will take my Daughter purely for her intrinſick value, and expect nothing with her, I may perhaps be perſwaded to part with her.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Here's a Parents affection; and yet he's every moment thund •• ing in my ears fi • ial duty, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Well, at preſent I have ſome buſineſs of conſequence to diſpatch, I'll therefore leave her with you: but be ſure that amongſt your many pious inſtructions, ply her home with the fifth Commandment, deſcant well upon that I ſay; ſo that reverend old age may keep its lawful Soveraignty.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: O good, Sir, what ſmall Talent I have either in argument or eloquence, ſhall certainly be employ'd for the ſervice of Sir Wealthy Plainder, and for the real good and eſſential benefit of pretty Madam Ophelia here—I'll take care ſhe ſhall accompany me to my daily Devotions.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Devorions! As for Devovions, do you mind me, I do not think 'tis a pin matter. If ſhe asks me bleſſing, do you ſee, 'tis enough, 'tis enough in all conſcience.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: And that I ſhould go without, were the purchaſe of it any more than a bare God a mercy.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Well, mind what I have ſaid, and ſo, do ye ſee, fare you well. Da, da, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Come, pretty Madam Ophelia, now you and I are together in private, we may take the liberty to open our Souls freely. Diſſimulation is a looſe upper garment, that may be laid aſide at pleaſure.

div.stage: Sir Bellamour appears at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Now the old Cockatrice begins to appear in her proper colours.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: You are young, Madam, and conſequently muſt have wiſhes; ſoft, young, tender wiſhes, which wiſhes may be ſatisfied, ſo it be within the rules of deſcretion.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: If diſcretion direct our wiſhes, I am confident they can never tend to any thing that is vicious—Well, ſince 'tis not in the power of Mankind to ſhock my principles, or tarniſh my vertue, I'll for once counterfeit a levity, and ſee what ſhe would be at (Aſide.) I muſt confeſs, Mrs Sweetny, that I do believe the ſhackles of ignorance to be the greateſt burden that can be impos'd upon us Mortals. I am therefore very willing to ſurrender my ſelf to ye, that I may be better inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: That's my good Girl, doſt thee know what love is, Child?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p:
Not very well: But I have heard 'tis ſomething that of a ſudden plays and dances about the heart, and from thence gradually trickles along the Veins, till having diffus'd itſelf into ſubtle rays, i •
ſteals out at the corners of the Eyes to reach the object of deſire.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha, a pretty notion truly of Loves firſt Onſet. But I muſt tell you, that were Love to do nothing elſe, than what is perform'd by ineffectual glances Well, I'll ſay no more, theſe are many gay, young, Sparks about the Town. Let opportunity ſhew ye further—What think you of Mr Vainthroat that came up to Town with you? Ah! He's a pure man▪—Od, ſo, ſee where he comes. How do you do, good Mr Vainthroat, after your Journey?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Pretty well, Madam, but methinks I want to divert my ſelf with ſome of my old hearty Bottle friends.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: And pray can't you no way divert your ſelf with us that are Women?

sp.speaker: Vain
sp.p: Faith, Madam, not eaſily; for generally you that are Women, either affectation makes you troubleſome, pride makes you imperious, or an over eaſineſs makes you nauſeous.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Such tempers are often aſſum'd, Sir, when at ſo cheap a rate a woman can free herſelf from ſome of your impertinent and coxcombly addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: I thought Mr Vainthroat had been better bred, than to expreſs himſelf in general terms, before particular Company, eſpecially before a Lady every way ſo deſerving, as is Madam Ophelia here.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam, I am ſufficiently acquainted with the bright Ophelia • s perfections, to except her from the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: I am ſure not a Member of the Sex, ought ever to value what is ſaid by a publick Detractor.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Detraction! why 'tis by that alone that I have inſinuated my ſelf into the intimate acquaintance of all the Women of Quality about the Town.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Come, Mr Vainthroat, you ſhall attone for your Fault by giving us a Song.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam; but I wiſh by that means I do not commit a greater.

div.head: SONG.
div.l: THE Riddle of Nature,
Is a Female Creature;
She's graciouſly proud,
Maliciouſly good,
And her buſineſs is to be idle.
The myſterious Toy,
If ſhe weep 'tis for joy,
And when ſhe beguiles,
'Tis done with her ſmiles,
He's mad then that bites of the Bridle.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: O fie upon you, for you're a ſad man—Have you ſeen Madam Thoroſhift yet, Mr Vainthroat.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Yes, faith, ha, ha, ha, poor Widow, I pity her e'gad, if ſhe lets that Tenement of hers ſtand a little longer uninhabited, it will be difficult for the next poſſeſſor to make good repairs.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p:
I'll promiſe you, Sir, ſhe does not want applications, but her prudence makes her cautious—Come, ſhall us walk into
the Dining Room, by this time I believe my Lord Courtipoll may be come.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis done! 'tis done. That heart that till now ne're felt a ſingle throb, is become all over pangs—I muſt own, that at firſt ſight I thought her beautiful; and what I have now overheard, aſſures me that her virtue is ineſtimable.—Oh Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: By hard ſhift I have ſlipt the Company of that wicked Seducer. And now I ll retire to my chamber, to enjoy the true pleaſure of thinking.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Bleſs me! She's here (ſtarting.) Madam.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Do ye diſcover nothing by my looks?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir Bellamour, I always thought you lookt ſomething cynical: And I believe you are now running mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: My paſſion, I muſt confeſs, is ſomething furious. Love is a ſort of madneſs.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: The knowledge of your Diſtemper is half your cure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Will you ſuffer your pitty to aſſiſt in the cure?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: I am not credulous enough to think that you have any occaſion for it.—However, I can't ſtay to diſcuſs the point with you at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Why ſo? where are you going then?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: I'll ſoon try his reality. (aſide.) May you be truſted, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Indeed I may, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Then know I'm going to my Chamber, to fetch my Mask, Hood and Scarf, and ſo jaunt it a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell
sp.p: Jaunt it!—What's the meaning of that?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Why that's to take a Hackney Coach, ſcowr from Playhouſe to Playhouſe, till I meet with ſome young Fellow that has power enough to attack me, ſtock enough to treat and preſent me, and folly enough to be laugh'd at for his pains.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Sure that Devils impliment, my Landlady, has not already induc'd her unexperienc'd youth.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Have you any thing elſe to ſay to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: A great deal, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p:
Then when I have nothing elſe to do, I'll hear you; and ſo
〈…〉 loving Sir Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p:
Well, tho I am not cut out for a ſoft Lover, I have a reſolution that's capable of perſevering. And if I miſtake not, I do already make plain diſcoveries through the thin veil of my Miſtreſſes pretences;
ſo that till a farther opportunity, I ſhall reſt ſatisfied that I have ad • ſerving object for my paſ • ion, and entruſt to her and fate for a ſuitable ſucceſs.

div.stage: Enter Captain Bownceby, and Widow Thoroſhift.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray Captain, what do you think the world would ſay on me, ſhould I beſtow my ſelf and fortune on a perſon—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Halt, halt good Madam: before you ſay a word on my perſon, pray be ſo kind as to view me well Do but mind this capacious Breaſt; theſe robuſt Shoulders, the ſturd ••… ſs of my Chi • e, the bre ••… h of my Ga • kins, the true turn and ſymetry of my Limbs, and the length of my Foot.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Your perſon I muſt confeſs is not deſpicable, but then, Sir, your •••… ion, where you may come to expoſe your l • fe—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Halt. halt again. I ſay, if 〈◊〉 once cope with my Widow, adieu Scarlet E'ſaith. If ever I ſpill drop of blood in the Field more, may my 〈◊〉 be food for Ravens, and my Bones lie blanching upon a Country Common.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But then Captain, without an Eſtate where's an equivolent for my Fortune?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: An equivolent, Madam! Why this perſon of mine that you have al • eady view'd, is more than equivolent for an Earldom, if inherited by a puny Lanthorn-back • t Chitty-fac't Stripling.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.p: Look ye, Captain, I queſtion not but you know that I am addreſs'd to by Mr Broakage, a wealty Merchant; and I have no ſooner mentioned him, but ſee where he comes, for the preſent Ill leave you together.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did you never hear of Captain Bownceby?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I have heard of ſeveral Captain Bowncebys, Captain Hackums, and Captain Kick and Cuffs. And what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I find this Mungrel has got Beef and Pudding in his paunch, and I believe dare ſight (aſide.) I ſay, Sir, do you know what Captain Bownceby can do if he pleaſes?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I know what the Law will ſuffer him to do; and if he does more than that—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Then, Sir, his big looks may chance to dwindle into a Tyburn grin.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ay Sir, 'tis well you have got Tyburn on your ſide, or let me tell you, Mr Broakage ſhould not have out-liv'd his laſt words, ſcar • y my Carcaſs if he ſhould.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Gentlemen the Widow has over-heard your high words, and ſent me to tell you, that if you don't this moment accommodate your differences, and embrace as friends, ſhe'll never ſee the face of either of you while ſhe breaths again; therefore if you have any value for her, I hope you'll not diſpute the executing her Commands.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Mrs Nibs, the Widow ſhall be obey'd by Captain Bownceby, and all the Bowncebys in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: And by me Benjamin Broakage, and all the Broakages in the Univerſe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Honeſt Mr Broakage!

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Dear Captain Bownceby!

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: A couple of Coxcombs!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You ſhall for the future command me and all my Weapons, even from my Bagonet to my Back-ſword.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: And you my Purſe, from the Decus's to the Jacobus's.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Is it ſo? Gad then it ſhan't be long before I borrow Money of him, I'll promiſe him.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, what think ye of ſtrengthening your friendſhip with a Health to the Widow, and ſo binding your bargain with a Bottle?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: With all my heart, Mrs Nibs.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Come along then.

div.stage: Enter Minx and Doll, followed by Sir Wealthy Plainder.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: What the dickings is the matter with ye, to be always thus teazing a body when you come to Town?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Matter my Minky! Why I love my Minky. Piddy my Minky let me go a little into dy Chamber widdee; wou't a my Minky?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: My Chamber! don't you think I • ll let any thing in the ſhape of Man enter my Chamber doors?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Odsboblikins let me go in any other ſhape then: Tye a Collar about my neck and lead me thither in the ſhape of Towzer, if dow tinkſt fit, my Minky. Nay, I'll be dy Puſſy-cat, dy Puppy-dog, dy any ting, my little pitty Minky.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: None of theſe ſhapes will do indeed, Sir Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Shall I come then, like another Jove, in the ſhape of— (Chinks a Purſe of Gold) Doſt thou hear the bleſſed chink, hea Gi • l?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Alack Sir, you have ſuch winning ways with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: I call, and I call, catch Minky; edad there be Purſe and all, my Child a grace, there's Gold for thee.—Edad I'm old Sir Wealthy ſtill, tho I've ſold my Eſtate, plead poverty to the world, and have ſwore my ſelf not worth a groat, on purpoſe to avoid paying the Kings Taxes.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p:
A very conſcientious Commonwealth • -man truly. (aſide)
Well, Sir, I have bethought of a way take to you into my Chamber unſuſpected—Doll, go and fetch hither one of your quondam Country Habits, ſhe and I will dreſs you up, and if my Lord Courtipoll comes, I'll pretend you are my old Nurſe juſt come out of the Country—But be ſure, whatever you do, don't ye diſcover your ſelf, if you do, you'll ruin me for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: E'dad this is a pure contrivance: And never Nurſe hugg'd a Bantling, as I'll hug thee for this invention. (hugs her) Ah my Minky.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Come, come ſtrip off your Jerkin, and let's dizen you.

div.stage: (They dreſs him up in womens Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Hold up your head Gammer, and mump and ſimper a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Nay I believe I ſhall not wholly unbecome a womans Dreſs, for I have features, Chicken; features, tho I ſay it, that are not altogether deſpicable—See, ſee how I can roll my Eyes about; and then pout out a plump under-lip, that would make the mouth of a Hermit to water again.

sp.speaker: Minx and Doll.
sp.p: Ah, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Now if any body ask you any queſtions, take your Apron thus,—drop two or three Curtzies, and ſay, I forſooth, and No forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye, let me alone for I forſooths and No forſooths.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: O Lord Miſtreſs! does not Meaſter look juſt like Joan the Ale-wife, at our Church-yard ſtile?

div.stage: Enter Nickycrack, followed by Lord Courtipoll and Prim.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Madam Minx, here's my Lord Courtipoll.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Oh! my dear Country puggy.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: O my Lord! why would you ſtay ſo long from a body?

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: We men of buſineſs, my dear Pug, lie under that heavy curſe to have our pleaſures give way to our toyls. And now I talk of buſineſs, let me conſider a little. (pauſes.)—If ſo—Ay, ay, then it muſt be ſo—Here Prim, diſperſe my Footmen. Let one wait at the Secretaries Office, another at the Admiralty, and the reſt at the Foreign Miniſters, that I may have ſpeedy notice where my aſſiſtance is requir'd

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: So, under this pretence the Servants are now ſet at liberty, and each man may go viſit his own Pug if he pleaſes, and ſo follow the preſent bleſſed vocation of their politick Lord and Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ld Co • r.
sp.p: Who's this you have got with you, Pug?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: 'Tis my Nurſe, my Lord, that is juſt come out of the Country.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Bleſs me! did ever ſuch a ſweet Creature as thee art, ſuck at the breaſt of ſuch a Horſe-fac't Dame as this is? But hold, I • ll go ask her after ſome affai •• in the Country, that may in ſome meaſure relate to the State. Let me conſider—Good woman, is there ſtore of Acrons this year, ha?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: A notable politick State queſtion truly.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Nurſe, why don't ye anſwer my Lord?—I find the poor old woman is in a quandery, I believe ſhe never ſaw a Lord before.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: On my Soul that may very well be.—Nay, I my ſelf have known a whole monthly meeting of Country Juſtices ſtruck ſo dumb at the grandeur of my preſence, that it was ſcarce within the power of Stale Beer to ſet their Tongues a moving again.—But come what ſay ye, old Mrs Chue cud, are Acrons plenty or not, ha?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Nurſe, why don't ye anſwer, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Yes, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Then we may expect our Veniſon to be fat, if my Dog of a Keeper have the grace to keep the Pariſh Hogs out of the Park.—But hold, let me conſider—Now for ſome Domeſtick Intelligence: Is the Widow your Siſter marry'd yet? ha, Pug?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: She's not ſped yet, but o'reſtockt with Suitors, as we ſen in the Country.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Pretty Pug, thy Country language does become thee. But hold, let me conſider once again—I profeſs there ought to be a Statute of Reſtriction relating to the Widows of this Kingdom; they are generally ſo damn'd cunning in their Amours, that half a ſcore of Widows are ſufficient to enſlave all the young fellows about the Twon.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ah, my Lord, the young fellows about the Town are not ſo eaſily enſlav'd in this age of Liberty.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: O my Lord Courtipoll, I can't but with Reverence acknowledge the high honour your Lordſhip does my houſe, in letting its mean roof ſhadow a perſon of ſo much worth, goodneſs and wiſdom, as is the Lord Courtipoll.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Oh Mrs. Sweetny, you are always ſo laviſh in your expreſſions!—Ha! Bleſs me! I'm Planet-ſtruck—Never was an Aſtrologer more amaz'd at the diſcovery of a new Star, than I am at the ſight of that beautiful creature—Pray, Mrs. Sweetny, by what name and title muſt I ſalute this fair Angel?

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: 'Tis the beautiful Madam Ophelia. my Lord, Daughter to Sir Wealthy Plainder.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: So, my Lord I find is embarking himſelf for another piece of Gallantry.—His politick Lordſhip f • lls as naturally into new amours, as a Town Bully runs himſelf into freſh Rencounters.—Minx, Minx, ply thy ſtumps, or all is loſt, faith girl.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, you forget to bring your Pug the Lapdog you promis'd her, ſo you do.— (Runs to Sir Wealthy) Either take your Daughter away this moment, or never expect to ſee the face of me again— (Runs back to Lord Court.) Come, my Lord, will you go along with your Pug, and ſee how far I have workt upon the Petticoat I ſhew'd you, when you were here laſt.—Why don't ye ſpeak to your Pug?

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: I profeſs I was within my ſelf deciding an intricate State queſtion, and find it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: (aſide to Ophelia.) Huſſy I command you to retire. I ſay be gone inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: What wou'd this dry chopp'd Hag have?—Pray good woman don't you noſe me at this rate.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal,
sp.p: Ye young Baggage don't ye know me?

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: I'm reſolv'd I won't know him at preſent (aſide.) What means this ſawcy quean to blow her filthy breath in my face, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Ye young Jade you, I'm your Father: But if ye diſcover me look to't.

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: Alas the poor woman is beſide her ſences I find.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Huſſy I'll thump your Jacket for this. I cou'd find in my heart to tear ye in pieces.

div.stage: Grins and clenches his fiſts at her.

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: Here, pray let ſomebody lay hold on this Mad woman, ſhe talks of tearing me in pieces.

div.stage: Nick. lays hold on Sir Weal.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: What's the matter, what's the matter with the Nurſe, ha?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Alas, alas! the poor Nurſe is ſometimes troubled with fits, and I fear ſhe's now fallen into one.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Hold her down, hold her down Brother Nickycrack; and Doll do you run and fetch the Bottle of Spirit of Harts-horn, run quickly.

div.stage: Doll runs and brings a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O pox! I find the Nurſe proves to be the old Fornicator Sir Wealthy Plainder, (aſide.) So ſo, I find ſhe begins to recover.—Come, now let me alone with her, I'll take her, and give her a turn or two in the Air, and a dram of Aqua Mirabilis, which is the life of an old woman, and I'll warrant ye all will be well again.

div.stage: Exeunt Nick. and Doll leading out Sir Weal.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: I muſt go ſee however, that they don't carry the buſineſs too far, as bad as he is.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: What has this new-born Star left our Hemiſphere already, ha?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Go, go my Lord, I find you don't love your Pug, that ye don't; if you did, you would never have ſtood and ſtared upon a ſtrange face at that rate, indeed you wou'dn't.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Not love my Pug? By the Soul of Matchiavel but I do, and that's the greateſt oath a Stateſm • n can ſwear by—VVere I, my Dear, to gaze upon crowds of Angels, and ſhould my Pug be amongſt them, ſhe alone ſhould have th • laſt and fixing look.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: There's a kind Lord for ye. Come, my Lord, by this time I ſuppoſe Supper waits for your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Come along then.—And after that I and my charming Pug here,

div.l: In am'rous ſports will ſo Di ••• ely toy,

l.q: The God of Love ſhal • clap his wings for joy.

div.head: ACT III.
Scene continues a Room in Sweetny's Houſe▪

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: AH Mr Nickycrack, is it not a hard caſe for me that am but a poor Commoner, thus to be rivall'd by a Lord.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Lord, Sir Wealthy Plainder, why would ye not diſcover your ſelf and concerns to me?—All the world knows the ſincerity of honeſt Nickycrack.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Alas, alas! in this caſe there can be no remedy but patience. Now muſt I forſooth e'en draw in my Horns, ſneak off and dance Attendance, tho I am ſure to enter into a Steel courſe to cure my ſelf of the Spleen for't.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come, Sir Wealthy, do but open your ſelf-freely, and I'll engage to aſſiſt ye.

sp.speaker: Sir VVeal.
sp.p: Open my ſelf, I that I will with all my heart, and my Purſe too, I'll promiſe ye—I am not that indigent perſon I pretend my ſelf, but am as rich in reality as a Chymiſt is in fancy—There, Nickycrack, take this as an earneſt of my future intentions.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, I am now linkt to your ſervice by the very tye of gratitude: and ſo to the point, Sir; I very well know your affections for Mrs Minx, and have already thought of an Expedient, that if you be but conſenting, ſhall ſoon put ye in quiet poſſeſſion of the charming Fair.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal:
sp.p: Ah my dear Boy, propoſe it, propoſe it I ſay, and never doubt my conſent.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The buſineſs is this, I perceiv'd my Lord Courtipoll fix'd his eye upon your Daughter Ophelia, and then he lickt his Lips, bit his Thumbs, ſigh'd, and preſs'd his ſides with his Arms thus.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now, Sir, if you be but conſenting, that we ſhall endeavour to work up her inclinations.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Inclinations! 'Sbud, I ſay ſhe ſhall have inclinations if that be all. I'll undertake to enjoyn it by force of power paternal.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: A ſpeci • l Father e'ſaith

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: VVork • up quoth a! E'gad in this caſe ſhe ſhall be workt up, and workt down too, I'll promiſe her that.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Not ſo fierce, pray Sir, women are of a perverſe and refractory temper, and their wills muſt by gentle and inſinuating means be ſuppled into? compliance, and not raſhly forc't by violence. This I'll do, I'll firſt go and engage my Siſter Sweetny on our ſide, and don't ye doubt the effects.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Prithee do, my dear Boy, about it this moment I beg thee (ſmuggles him) So, now begone, Sirrah. (Exit. Nick.) I can 〈◊〉 think what a happy thing it was, that I had a pretty Daughter to 〈◊〉 me out at this dead lif • —VVell, I find Children may one time of other be worth their rearing.

div.stage: Enter Sir Bellamour Blunt and Vainthroat.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Sir Bellamour in love, pleaſant enough e'faith: why an amour, man, will ſit as awkardly upon thee, as a good ſuit of Cloaths does upon an uncouth Country Squire—But ſee yonder's your Father-in-law that is to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Rot him, he's a Brute.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: However, you muſt be civil to him on the account of Ophelia—Your Servant, Sir Wealthy, how goes it with our fellow Traveller?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: How can it go well with any Gentleman that is decay'd in his Fortunes, and as it were turned looſe into the world, eſpecially ſuch a baſe degenerated world as this is?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Faith I believe the world is as it uſed to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I am of your opinion, the rich dread diſaſters, and the poor contemn 'em. Fools wonder at what wiſe men foreſaw.—And potent Knavery depreſſes and preys upon meritorious honeſty; and ſo it was always, I believe.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: As for the female part of the world, I'm ſure it is as it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: How is that, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Why the dear charming Creatures are ſo coming, that there's not one in fifty but Cuckolds her Husband before ſhe has him—As thus Sir, when once a young couple have entertain'd a correſpondence, and that correſpondence ripens into warm deſires, and thoſe deſires require fruition, then ſhe immediately, for the ſecurity of Reputation, marries another, on purpoſe to give her Spark an opportunity to reap the Bleſſings freely—And that's Cuckoldom before Marriage for ye, at leaſt it's ſo intentionally▪

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: And pray Sir why could not the Lovers themſelves have marry • d?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: O Pox! that were the way to have had the joys pall'd upon their hands immediately. Marriage joys, foh!

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Vainthroat thou'rt a horrible cenſorious fellow; and abundantly too general in thy reflections • elating to the fair Sex. Sir Wealthy Plainder, if you pleaſe, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Your pleaſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: You have a Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: I have ſo: And 'tis well I have, as the caſe ſtands, I can tell you that Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, I think her extremely Beautiful.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: So much the better for my purpoſe ſtill, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: In ſhort, I love her.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: And to be as ſhort as you, you are not like to have her, nor have I any thing to give her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: My affections are above a bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: And below the mark, I'll tell ye that.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: How ſo, Sir, I hope our qualities are equal.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: In ſhort, I have engag'd her to a perſon above your quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Who's that, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Why then to be plain with you, 'tis to my Lord Courtipoll.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Lord Courtipoll! why he's married.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Married! What then, ha, ha, ha, mayn't he have occaſion for my Daughter for all that? Ha, ha, ha, married, that's a good one e'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: What does the old Rogue mean, would he proſtitute his own Daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt beg your pardon, for I am this moment going to ſee them fairly put together: and ſo your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Oh horrid Monſter! however, I don't queſtion but the young Ladies Virtue will ſtand the ſhock, and baffle the intentions of this villain, and ſo render herſelf the moſt adorable Creature upon the face of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Mrs Nibs, you ſeem to have diſcretion, and I believe you may be confided in.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Sir, I'll endeavour to merit your good opinion, by any ſervice you ſhall pleaſe to command me—In the firſt place you may be aſſur'd of my ſecrecy.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Pray Sweet-heart accept of this ſmall token, [Gives money] I doubt not but that you are acquainted with the affairs of the Family.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: That I am, Sir; there is nothing that is done, ſaid, or ſcarce thought of under this Roof, that is unknown to your very humble Servant Nibs Truſty.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Then, Mrs Nibs Truſty, I need not tell ye that there are at preſent baſe things in agitation.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I know what you mean, tho I will ſay but little. Madam Ophelia is to be ſacrificed to the pleaſures of my Lord Courtipoll, to gratify her old doting Fathers paſſion for Mrs Minx, his Lordſhips preſent kept Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I find your intelligence is authentick.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I am not unac •• ainted neither with your pretenſions to the beautiful Ophelia—What is it now you'd have me do?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Only to give me a punctual notice of proceedings.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I'll do it on the forfeiture of my life. And more than that, I'll aſſiſt ye to countermine any Plots that ſhall be laid againſt the young Lady's Honour—You ſeem to be a man of worth, and I have ſound ye a perſon of Generoſity, therefore aſſure your ſelf that in your affairs I'll be as diligent as a Court-Procurer, aud as ſecret as a Mother Mid-night. This moment I'll ſee how things go on: and ſo I am Sir Bellamour's moſt humble Servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: But come, prithee Vainthroat give me ſome account of this Lord Courtipoll, and look you deal ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, What, Knight, art ſtung already with that peſtiferous Viper Jealouſie?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I'm not diſtruſtful, but cautious.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, upon my word my Lord Courtipoll is a dangerous Rival, Folly and Profuſeneſs are taking qualities among the Ladies. And faith they are i'th' right on't; for how can a Woman better ſecure her pleaſures, than when ſhe commands the Purſe of a liberal Fool?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: For my part, I ſhan't think him dangerous; for I'm confident Ophelia has Diſcretion enough to laugh at his Folly, and a ſufficient ſtock of Virtue to deſpiſe the baſeneſs of his Bribes.

sp.speaker: Vain▪
sp.p: Come, Sir Knight, that you may ſhake off this moody amorous temper, I'll entertain you with a Song and Dance.

lg.l: LEt never dull ſorrow our joys invade,
But for ever let's follow the toping trade:
Drive the Current of Time along;
He's a Prince of a Man
And makes it a Cubit long.
Call Harry to fetch us more Bottles in,
Don't tarry, ſince to Revel we thus begin:
Till the Moon and Stars are gone;
That they Rival the Riſing Sun

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: So, very well—To morrow you ſhall range the Town along with me▪ A Wench and a Bottle is a certain Antidote againſt the poyſon of Love: But for the preſent let's go and divert our ſelves with the follies that this Family of ours can afford us.

div.stage: Enter Captain Bownceby Drunk. (A Table with Candle • .)

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Toll, doll, di, da, doll. (Roars out of Tune.) Huzzah, Victoria, Victoria! Ha, ha, ha; He drink with me, a peddling Prig, 'sbud I've laid him as dead as a Door-nail. And now for the Widow, By the Soul of a Culverin, I cou'd in this humour make Love like a Dragon.—Come, faith I'll go practice a little. Here ſhall ſtand the Widow, (Sets a Chair out) and here ſhall ſtand the Whelp Broakage, ſneaking up in this corner; (Sets his Perriwig upon his Cane in the corner) ſtand there, you Hell-hound: and if you dare but to look towards me, during the Adoration I ſhall pay my Charming Goddeſs here, I'll that moment tear out of your head thoſe Sacrilegious Eye Balls—Now I'll begin; Madam, tho I've long been a Man of Terror, and have made Conflagrations, Plundering, Rapes, and Throat-cutting my ſport and diverſion, yet for the ſake of your dear ſelf, I'll now, like a ſecond Hercules, fling by my Club and take up the Diſtaff—The roaring Lion ſhall clap his Tail betwixt his Legs, and become a fawning Spaniel to lick the duſt off your Ladyſhips Shooe-ſoles—But firſt, Madam, let me beg leave to ſacrifice yonders ſniveling Whore • bird, up in the corner there, to my own vengeance, and for your Ladyſhips honour. (Draws his Sword, and goes to the Cane and Perriwig) Come along then; by the fiery breath of a Demi-Cannon, I'll murther this Whelp and Bacon this very minute, that I will, you Villain, ye Mongril, you Lick-ſpit Cur ye. (Lays about him with his Sword) I'll mince your fleſh for ye, and ſo feed young Jackdaws with the morſels—So, ſo, now I think 'twill be convenient to repoſe my ſelf a little after this plaguy fatigue.

div.stage: (Sheaths his Sword, ſits down in the Chair, and falls aſleep.

sp.speaker: Nick Nibs, Nibs,
sp.p: what's the matter with the Captain here, he is fallen faſt aſleep.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Why I left him and Mr Broakage in the Buttery, drinking the Widows health upon a reconciliation, and I find they have made one another drunk.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: E • gad let's play him ſome trick or other, and try to ſtartle this undaunted Hero.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: With all my heart. VVe will take out the Candles, and get the Trumpets my Lord Courtipoll has brought to rattle him awake of a ſudden, and ſee how he'll bear it.

div.stage: Nick and Nibs take out the Candle, Trumpets ſounds a Charge.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: (ſtarting up) Good Lord where am I, or what is become of me. (Re-enter Nickycrack with a Candle) Ah! good dear Sir, tell me where I am, or what is become of me.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Captain Bownceby, 'tis I, your friend Nickycrack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then I find I have been dreaming all this while.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But why this cold ſweat? why all this fear, good Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: VVhy would ye have a man have courage in his ſleep, that is a jeſt indeed. Now I am awake, Mr Nickycrack, I muſt tell you, that there is nothing upon the face of the earth, that can terrify Captain Bownceby; nay, I defy the King of Terrors himſelf, and all his Hellborn Guard de Corps. But hark ye, dear Nickycrack, prethee tell me how doſt think my affairs ſtand with the VVidow?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: On my Soul, as you can wiſh your ſelf. Ah Captain! I have heard her ſpeak very feelingly of that graceful perſon of yours.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Very like ſo I vow, for I took care to make her view me diſtinctly. And what if I take an opportunity to palm the true dimenſions uodn her? ha, Boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now's your time to bear up briskly: Your Rival Mr Broakage is dead drunk in the Buttery; and I'll contrive to ſecure him for one hour at the leaſt, don't queſtion it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Egad then I'll go ſtrike her home. I'll firſt go waſh and tallow, and then—Have at thy Coat, old VVidow.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But Captain, methinks you're ſomethiug forgetful of your faithful ſervant, Mr. Nickycrack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not at all, I proteſt Sir. Ods life man, the Arrears are not yet paid, when they come in thou ſhalt ſwim in Money: by the bar • el of a Blunderbuſs thou ſha't, my Boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But Sir, if you pleaſe, in the mean time to ſign this ſmall Note, it will encourage the work ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That I will my Lad, I'll ſign it as freely as ever I ſign'd a falſe Muſter-Roll. Let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: So, Sir, now away to the Widow, and Heavens proſper ye; in the mean time I'll take care of Mr Broakage.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then faith I'll loſe no time—Adieu.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well Nibs, I have got the Captain in black and white here; and now I'll go try to get the Merchant under the ſame circumſtances.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I have been examining the Merchants Cargo for him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well! and how, was he richly laden?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Hang him, I'll be far enough if he is not a Bankrupt, he had not one ſouſe of Ready in's pocket.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What Bills had he Child?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Bills he had indeed, of Taylour, Surgeon, Landlady, Cook, and Landreſs, but not one ſingle Bill of Credit.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The leſs favour he is like to find at my hands, I'll promiſe him. Come, let's go order matters to the beſt advantage. Exeunt.

div.stage:
Enter 〈◊〉
Courtipoll following Ophelia. A Table and Chairs.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Hold! let me conſider! what ſhall I ſay firſt?—Oh now I have it. Do you know who I am, Madam, ha?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to be in earneſt with this politick Blockhead. I'll e'n play upon the fool to make my ſelf diverſion. (aſide)—You, Sir, are a perſon of noble quality.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Right, Madam, I am ſo.—And pray, Madam, how came you to know that I was a man of noble quality, ha?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Your mein and perſon beſpoke you ſo, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Very like ſo, I vow—Gad I'll try her parts a little farther, (aſide.) And do you know what I am famous for?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: No doubt, for your wiſdom, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Ay, ſay ye ſo?—Why ſhould you think ſo, pray, ha?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: By the ſolemn air of your countenance, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: By the ſoul of Matchiavel, ſhe's a meer Sybil, (aſide.) What then do you think me moſt fit for; ha, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: To ſit at the Helm of Government, and ſteer the State, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: O bleſs me! I vow Madam you're a perſon of the cleareſt apprehenſion that ever I yet converſed withal. Should I have a Son by you, I'd forfeit my honour if he did not bid fair for the Crown of Poland, ſhould there chance to be an Election by the time he came of age. But now to the buſineſs in hand: Come, pray let's ſit down, and I will make love to you as becomes a Stateſman, by asking of ſome politick queſtions. (They ſit down, my Lord pauſes a while)—Ay that will do. Pray, Madam, which ſide do you lie on when you ſettle your ſelf to ſleep? ha, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: What can the Coxcomb mean by this? however, at the preſent, I'm reſolved to humour him. (aſide.)—I always ſleep on my left ſide, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Then I am the happieſt man in the world, I find the Heavens are propitious to our Amours; for you muſt know I always ſleep on my right, ſo that I, each night • laſpt within thy circling arms, ſhall coo, pur, and murmur out my love with the greateſt tranſports imaginable.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: This I muſt confeſs, was a rapture worthy a Politician.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: But hold, let me conſider once again!—Ay, if ſo, then that may very well be.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, if this be politick Love, it is a very cool way of proceeding.

div.stage: Enter. Minx ſtruggling with Sir Wealthy Plainder, and boxing him.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Hold out of the way, you old doting fool ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Odslifelikius ſhe has made my ears ſing again; what a plaguy ſtrength did the young vixon ſtrike withal.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: So ſo, is this going to ſee a Packet opened? You a perſon of quality, and tell a lie.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: You miſtake, Pug, a Stateſman can't tell a lie, he only gives out falſe intelligence to amuſe and gain advantage.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: A fig for a Stateſman, don't tell me of a Stateſman, ne're a Stateſman in Chriſtendom ſhall abuſe me. Don you think to leave me in this condition, without providing either for me or my burthen here. By jenkins before I will be ſerv'd ſo, I'll take up the Fire-ſork and crack the very skull of you, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Patience, patience, Pug—E'gad I'll comply, for it may be a fatal thing for a Politician to receive a very ſmall blow, if it chance to hit in the right place.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Come, come away, will you? The Lawyer waits for you, will you go in and ſeal the Writings, or no?

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: That I will, my Pug, I never deſigned otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Come along then. Come, Sir Wealthy, you ſhall go and be witneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam; ods life, if his Lordſhip delivers I'll take poſſeſſion e'faith.

div.stage: [Ex. Ld Court. Minx. and Sir Weal. Enter Nibs.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I gueſt, Madam, at your uneaſineſs, and therefore ſoon contrived your relief.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: And I gueſs who imploy'd ye, and therefore ſhall take care to keep you in the dark.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Did not you find his Lordſhip very troubleſome and impertinent?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Not at all. How can a perſon of his quality be thought troubleſome, or a man of his parts be reckoned impertinent.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I ſcarce believe you to be ſerious.
