I know you, Madam Ophelia, to have a better judgment; but there is a perſon in the world, tho I'll ſay nothing of him, who has no ſmall eſteem for you, and is really a man of parts, an honeſt Gentleman, whoſe pretenſions are honourable: what think you of Sir Bellamour Blunt, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: I think he is a Hog, ameer Hog; who do you think would be troubled with his moroſeneſs?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: It is his true notion of things, and the ſincerity of his principles that makes him ſo downright, both in his diſcourſe and actions: but here he comes, let him ſpeak for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Are you now at leiſure to hear me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: No, nor never will be at leiſure to hear any body but my Lord

sp.speaker: Courtipoll.
sp.p: Well Sir, if you have any buſineſs at Court, I may perhaps prevail with my Lord Courtipoll to intercede for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Thank my Stars, my buſineſs there is equal to his intereſt, which—.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Hold, no reflections upon a noble Courtier, pray Sir? They ought to be above cenſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Nay his Lordſhip may be a great Courtier as far as I know. Gay fools often ſerve for the ornamental furniture of a Court—Tho this is not my buſineſs at preſent. Now I have an opportunity I muſt tell you, that I have a ſtrong and ſincere paſſion for you.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Paſſion! Ha, ha, ha. And I muſt tell you that I have a ſtrong and ſincere averſion to all manner of paſſion, eſpecially a fooliſh lovepaſſion. 'Tis a turbulent ſtorm of the mind, that raiſes a ſhort bluſtring diſorder, but ſoon, alas, flags into a cool regardleſs calm.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Mine, Madam, is of a temperament that promiſes duration.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Many things that are very promiſing, meet with ſtrange alterations before th • ir events.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Have you had any account of this Lord Courtipoll?

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he has kept a Miſtreſs, and what by that? we're not to expect Saints about the Town in this Age—The very bulchin Country Calf, that till the age of one and twenty ſucks the Teat, and bleats at the heels of his Lady Dam, ſoon finds an opportunity to lick the face of ſome homely Heifer or other.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Do ye know that he's Marry'd, and what function you are deſign'd for?

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p:
The thoughts of this, I muſt confeſs, in ſpight of my pretenſions, ſhocks the very ſoul of me, and fires me all over with Indignation. (Aſide.)
Enter Sir Wealthy Plainder.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: O fie, O fie, come along with me, Huſſy, quickly.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, your Perriwig is a fire, your Perriwig's afire, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Where, where?

div.stage: (As he flings off his Hat and Perriwig, rubs his Head, and jumps about, Ophelia ſteals off another way.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: 'Tis out now, Sir: And all's well again.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: (looking about.) Where's Ophelia?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: She's ſtept in before you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Edad then I'll after her.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a barbarous horrid fellow, as this Sir Wealthy?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Come, Sir Bellameur, all will go well, I'll warrant you. I can ſee as far into a Millſtone as another body: and can foretell the ſucceſs of an Amour better than e're a Fortune-teller in the Kingdom: Tho I love to ſay but little, I don't queſtion but I ſhall bring all things about, and give you the poſſeſſion of both the Lady and a conſiderable Fortune into the bargain, out of her Fathers conceal'd Treaſure. For tho I never do diſcover Secrets, yet I muſt tell you, that, for all Sir Wealthy pleads poverty at this rate, yet the old Rogue is as rich as a Jew. You ſhan't want my aſſiſtance I promiſe ye, Sir Bellamour. But mum's the word, not one ſyllable more. And for your comfort,

div.l: At Games of Love, where Lovers tug moſt hard,
'Tis truſty Nibs that proves the ſureſt Ca • d▪

div.head: ACT IV.
Scene continues a Room in Mrs. Sweetny's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sweet
sp.p: WEll, and pray Madam what proceedings is there in your grand affair of Love?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Indeed Mrs. Sweetny I'm at laſt drove to take my choice of two Extreams, either to be ſtript, and flung into durance, by the force of Law Temporal▪ or to be diveſted of all freedom, and deliver my ſelf into Matrimonial bonds, by the power of Law Spiritual.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: If you'll be advis'd by me accept of the latter, for in that the tye is mutual: And your knowledge of the world will direct you to looſe your own hands at pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then as to my choice of perſons, whether I ſhall take that palpable Fool of a Captain, or the ſhrewd ſuſpected Knave of a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Where there is a plentiful Eſtate a Fool may be very convenient▪ But in your circumſtances the Merchant, that, no doubt, is well acquainted with all manner of ſubtle Tricking, wou'd, I think, be the fitter Match.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: They have both my promiſe to diſpatch the buſineſs this very night, and they equally confide in't.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, dear Madam, that I look upon both of 'em of very uncertain worth. I wiſh you wou'd take Courage, prune, briſtle, and diſplay your Charms ſo, that you might entangle the affections of honeſt Sir Bellamour Blu • t; he's a man of a known value.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Alas his gruffſhip is already viſibly faſten'd: Don't you ſee how he • lounces about after the tail of your new gueſt Ophelia?

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Here comes his friend Vainthroat, we'll engage him in the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Where have you been, good Mr Vainthroat, we have wanted you ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Vain
sp.p: Why faith, Madam, I have been, like an out-lying Deer, browſing about a little in freſh paſture▪ and am now very coolly return'd within the pale again.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Come, ſweet Sir, what think ye of promoting a Match betwixt the Widow here and your friend Sir Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, promote do ye call it? I think there is not three pence difference in the piece of ſervice, either to promote a friend ſix • ounds up an Execution-Ladder, or as many ſteps towards Matrimony.

div.stage: Sir Bellamour Blunt appears at a diſtance, walking in a melancholy poſture.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: ſings in a Ballad tone.

div.l: But ſee where walks the doughty Knight,
Who all in doleful guiſe,
Metes out the time of ſable night.
With Tears dropt from his Eyes.
div.p:
Widow, Widow, I vow yonders Champion ſeems to lye under ſome dire Enchantment, prithee go try whether you have ever a Spe ••
about you that's powerful enough to ſet him at liberty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I'll uſe my endeavour to unſhackle him: But it ſhall be with deſign to ſecure him within a Circle of my own▪ I promiſe him a that.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Come, ſweet Madam Thoroſhift, you ſhall ſhew a Female proweſs in attacking this ſowre Knight of the Lees. I'll conduct you into the Liſts, and leave you to manage the Combat as you ſee convenient. (Sweetny and Widow walk up towards Sir Bellamour.) I hope honeſt Sir Bellamour won't think much to be left alone with a handſome young Widow. Pray let me enjoyn you that Love be the ſubject of your diſcourſe, and look that you handle the matter warmly—Come Mr. Vainthroat let's leave them together.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But do ye think, Sir, there's no Charms in the world that equals Ophelia's? To my knowledge there's a certain perſon, that, without offence, for Features, for Complexion, for Shape, for Air, for Mien; nay more, one that knows how to—

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Render herſelf Ridiculous, by a nauſeous, falſe commendation.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, come, a Woman of Diſcretion, and of a kind, complying temper, as I know who is, will bear with any thing that comes from Sir Bellamour Blunt.—Will you ſuffer—

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: The Rack rather than this Impertinence—What the Devil wou'd this woman have?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Have you to recollect your ſelf, and conſult your Reaſon. Do but think how mean a ſpirited thing 'tis, not to reſent the ſlights and affronts of a young wanton Coquet; and how ungenerous 'twou'd be, not to careſs the ſincere and obliging offers of a perſon—

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Who in Confidence epitomizes her whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
How, Confidence! I find you are one of thoſe tame fools that love to be ill us'd. And ſince you thus baſely refuſe my kind and
tender Compaſſion for you, I'll make you ſmart under the laſh of my Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: As long as I'm got clear of your Smiles, I'll ſtand the Battory of your Frowns at a diſtance. And ſo faith Lady I ſhall take my advantage, and ſheer off.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Was there ever any thing ſo provoking? A dull inſenſible Log: Efaith I'll plague him for this, I • ll warrant him.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Ah Madam, Madam, we •• e all undone, undone; yonders the Mob up in the City, raviſhing at ſuch a rate, you never heard the like on • t. They ſay there is not a Female left undefil'd twixt Algate and Ludgate.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then for my part, I believe the worſhipful the Mob have but left them as they found them.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord! why what, Madam, do ye offer to make a jeſt of Ravi • hing?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why it always was a jeſt, a meer jeſt, Nibs. I never yet ſaw it only repreſented on the Stage, but it created a ſatisfactory titt'ring amongſt all the Females in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: I have told my Lord Courtipoll of it, and he's going up into the City with all the haſte imaginable.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Come, now I'll ſhew the world how ſerviceable I can be to a State upon an emergent occaſion.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: O good my Lord make haſte, to be raviſht by a parcel of naſty Kennel-rakers would be inſufferable, were it to be by Gentlemen it were nothing.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Alas, poor thing.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But what my Lord, do ye mean to Drawcancer it, and ſingly encounter Multitudes?

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: No, no, Madam, I'll promiſe you I don't mean to ſtrike a ſtroke, I know better things▪ In the firſt place I'll make Speeches. Thus I'll begin: My loving Friends and dear Countrymen. As for the reſt I may truſt my genius to direct that happy Talent I have in Oratory. Madam, your Servant. But hold! E're I go, pray Mrs Nibs do you take this Ring, and whilſt 'tis warm with theſe three kiſſes, preſent it to the fair Ophelia, and let her put it on her middle finger on her left hand. And having alſo ſolemnly kiſt it three times, let her lay it cloſe to her heart, and then put up ſome ejaculations for her adventurous Lord Courtipoll. Such myſteries as theſe were always thought requiſite amongſt the ancient Politicians, upon the undertaking of any grand affair. Madam, your Servant. Come along 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Wid. Nibs,
sp.p: what have you done with my brace of Lovers, I am reſolved I'll ſoon decide the point in controverſie. But firſt I'll to my Chamber, to meditate Revenge upon this baſe fellow Sir Bellamour, to ſlight proffer'd Careſſes is an injury that a woman is never able to forgive.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: And I ſhall take care to blunt the edge of your malice on this occaſion, I'll promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, yonder's my Lord marcht up into the City to quell the Mob, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Han't I manag'd this project rarely? I have ſent his Lordſhip on this fools errand, ſo that my generous friend Sir Bellamour might have the greater freedom to proſecute his Amour with Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Faith 'twas well contriv'd, and I'll aſſiſt thee in any thing with all my heart, Girl.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Come along then.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Now Doll I am a little at eaſe; my Settlement is not only a ſufficient maintenance for my ſelf, but for any Spark that I ſhall beſt fancy; ſo that I may now when I think fit, turn honeſt with a ſafe Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: And your humble Servant Country Doll here is jumping into preferment apace. In the firſt place, I am to be married to ſuperabundantly nice Mr. Prim, and by that means I ſhall forthwith commence Gentlewoman, and become acquainted with people of Quality: Then, no doubt, upon the diſcovery of ſome private qualifications that I am Miſtreſs of, I ſhall ſoon be reſorted to by the greateſt men in the Kingdom. Madam, ſhall I beg a ſmall favour at your Ladyſhips hands, ſays one Lord. It lies in your Ladyſhips power to relieve a perſon in very great diſtreſs, ſays another Lord. Oh how I'll briſtle when they come cringing to me for a Caſt of my function.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Gad a mercy Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: But what have you done, Madam, with Sir Wealthy Plainder? Certainly he's not to be neglected till he's a little better fleec'd.

sp.speaker: Minx
sp.p: Hang him, an old rivell • d skin impotent Cur, a bundle of dried Kexes would be a better bed fellow.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: What the Devil ſignifies his Carcaſs, ſo his Purſe be but proli • ick.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Well Doll, I'll freely remit both his Carcaſs and Purſe too into your hands, manage him as you think convenient; you may eaſily contrive to perſonate me, there is no danger that he can make any diſcovery of the cheat.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p:
Faith then I'll about it immediately, I'll go ſend him a challenge in your name, appoint ſome convenient place, and ſhould he prove backward, and refuſe to bleed freely, I'll firſt rifle the old
Rogue, then beat him into better manners. I know he carries two or three hundred pieces always about him, and I will rip the very Waſteband of his Breeches for him, but I'll find it out; ſuch a ſumm as that will furniſh me a ſmall ſecret Apartment with an Indian Pallet-Bed, and a large Glaſs at the head on't, a ſet of Dutch Nudities, a Silver Chocolate Pot, and a Punch Bowl, and ſome other pretty utenſils that are abſolutely neceſſary for one of my employ.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I fancy Doll thou't become thy promotion very well, indeed thou haſt ſomething in thy face that looks very reverend.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Nay I am confident I ſhall be as punctual in all the formalities of my Calling as any body. I can double my Chin, pout out a wanton Lip, wag the Head, and tip the wink, as well as e're a ſtanding Bawd in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Minx
sp.p: O rare Madam Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Well, Madam, with your leave I will now go look after Sir Wealthy Plainder, and manage that affair.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Do ſo Doll, and I will go ſee how my Siſter Thoroſhift goes on in her buſineſs.

div.stage: Scene changes to the Garden by Moon-light,

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Yonder's the Arbour that truſty Nibs promiſed to decoy Ophelia too. 'Tis to be hoped that the ſerenity of the night, and the ſweetneſs of the place, may ſo becalm her boſom, that it will be the more ſuſceptible of the ſoft inſpirations of love.

div.stage: (Goes into the Arbour. Enter Sir Wealthy Plainder with a ſmall Trunk, Sir Bell. peeping out of the Arbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: So, under this Bench will I conceal my dear, dear Treaſure here, (Kiſſes and hugs the Trunk.) till the damn'd ravenous Mob be quell'd. Sure no body ſees me but the Moon yonder, and a my Conſcience, Madam Luna ſcorns to tell tales: had ſhe been a blab of her Tongue, the Gods would never have choſe her out for a Midwife—So, now I'll to my Minky, and recreate the fleſh a little. I'll make the young Jade practice a thouſand pretty Dalliances; ſhe ſhall rub my Ears, clap my Cheeks, ſcratch my Knees, and tickle me under the ſhort Ribs, e'faith, Ee, e, e, e, I'll ſhew her how, I'll ſhew her how preſently.

div.stage: Exit. Sir Bellamour Blunt comes out of the Arbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p:
A pox of thy damn'd laſcivious hide, for an old doting Letcher—However, methinks this proves very lucky. I may certainly, with all the juſtice in the world, carry off this old
villains belov'd Wealth—And ſo conſtitute my ſelf Truſtee for the much wronged Ophelia.

div.stage: Carries the Trunk into the Arbour. Enter Ophelia and Nibs.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Here is a lovely night, Madam; the Sky looks clear and glorious, the Air is freſh, and the Banks are fragrant.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: The night is pleaſant indeed, and the place agreeable.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: And very ſuitable for Love Adventures, is it not, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: The truth on it is, this might be a proper Scene for ſome of the idle Romantick Stories we meet withal in Novels—As when Olimpia, lying under the conſtraint of ſevere Parents, being wholly debarr'd the object of her affections, reſtleſs in bed, ſhe ſlips on a looſe Garment, takes her Lute, and ſteals gently forth into the Garden, where, having burthen'd the ambient Air with preſſing ſighs, and long complain to the regardleſs Plants, at length the lovely Nymph warbles out ſome ſoft and killing words made of her abſent Swain. Celadon, conceal'd in an adjacent Arbour, ſurpriz'd with the unlookt for harmony, ruſhes out of his melancholy covert, flings himſelf at the feet of his charming Goddeſs, and there expires in the higheſt Tranſport of an amorous paſſion.

div.stage: She ſpeaks this ſlightingly, as ridiculing the matter.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: And would not this, Madam, look very prettily, were it to be performed in reality? Pray let me beg of you to begin the ſtory at the Song, and ſee how fate may order the Conſequences.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: I will not deny you a Song, Nibs, but I believe the ſtory as you call it, is like to begin and end with it.

div.head: SONG.
div.l: ALL things ſeem deaf to my complaints,
In vain I roam the Groves along.
Hear me ye Loves departed Saints,
That to Elizyan ſhades are gone.
If to my faithful Celadon I prove not true,
Let it be both our dooms never to come to you.

div.stage: Sir Bellamour ruſhes haſtily from the Arbour, and flings himſelf at the Feet of Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: (ſhreiks out.) O—h! what piece of rudeneſs is this?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, 'Tis your faithful Celadon, Madam, expiring in the tranſports you juſt ſpoke of. And now to go on with the Novel. Olimpia, ſtruck at the ſudden amazement of her unexpected Celadon, continues for ſome time ſilent as the night, and ſenceleſs as a ſtatue, till recollecting the ſufferings of her faithful Swain, a relenting pity ſoon ſeizes her trembling heart, pity the kind harbinger of triumphant Love. What then ſhould enſue, but a whole train of Tears, Fires, Flames, Raptures, and ſo forth, which are things that never admit of a witneſs. I ſhall
therefore beg leave to drop a haſty Curtzie, (Curtzies) and ſo withdraw.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: (riſing.) Thou dear charming Creature!

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; what, have you been all this while ſtudying of that Speech—There's a flight with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: And muſt my paſſion for ever be the ſubject of your Raillery?

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: Your paſſion, I ſuppoſe, is like other mens, of the ſame continuance as your courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Cou'd I ſuppoſe my ſelf capable of altering my eſteem by a poſſeſſion, I'd ſooner tamely ſurrender my breaſt to be poſſeſt by Furies, nay, by Envy itſelf, the worſt of Fiends, rather than urge you one ſyllable farther.

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: So, ſo, I find your are reſolv'd to take a ſhare in the Novel; this is all Romantick to the higheſt degree.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I'm not us'd to any thing but truth, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ophel.
sp.p: Pray don't be angry, good Sir; aud I'll give you a piece of truth in return to your truth, you ſo much boaſt of—You muſt know then that my affections are at preſent a little upon the float; they may in time fix, and come to a ſediment, then if a draught of the dregs of Love will go down with your Conſtitution, I may perhaps have a doſe or two at your ſervice. And ſo adieu, ſweet Sir Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: How dare you be ſo ſaucy? Unhand me I ſay, or may I never—

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: (looſing her) No imprecations I beſeech you Lady, what I have to ſay nearly concerns your intereſt.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Out with it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Do but ſtep into this Arbour with me, and there—

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: There you'll play the Satyr perhaps, 'twill concern my intereſt truly, to give you an opportunity to proceed farther with this brutiſh force you have ſo rudely began.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Don't you thus wrong the innocence of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: If your intentions be juſt, why can't you make this grand diſcovery you pretend to, here in the place where we now are?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Stay but a moment and I'll convince ye.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: What can he be gone for?—Be it what it will, I am reſolv'd I will not ſtay to be convinced, ſatisfying a curioſity has ever been very fatal to our Sex.

div.stage: Exit, Re-enter Sir Bellamour with the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Ophelia, Ophelia.

div.stage: Widow Thoroſhift above at a Window.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That muſt be Sir Bellamour's voice. I'll take this opportunity and fling him the Letter I have prepared.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p:
Ha! (Taking up the Letter) Whence can this come I wonder •
it may perhaps contain what a Virgin modeſty might refuſe to diſcover face to face. (Opens the Letter) I can by Moon-light perceive that 'tis ſubſcrib'd Ophelia,
• tho I can't in this place read the Contents—I am impatient to read it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: So, the bait he ſwallows greedily, and I'll take care to ho • k him.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: This is the place appointed; and • m confident the old Dotard will punctually anſwer my Defiance—I vow here he comes already.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Minx, Minx, Minky, Minky, ha! ſure yonder muſt be Petticoats that are ſailing about there: 'Sboblikins if they be, I will make 'em fly preſently. VVhy Minky, Minky▪

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: So, this Arbour is a convenient place for the execution of my deſign—Here, here, Sir Wealthy

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: VVhere, where?

div.stage: (Anſwering int the ſame tone. Doll ſlips into the Arbour, and Sir VVealthy follows her.)

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: (within) A hey! why Huſſy, what a murrain ar't a doing. Nay Minky, don't play the fool with a body at this rate.

div.stage: Re-enter Doll with Sir VVealthy's Breeches.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: So, there let the old bearded Goat ſtand and cool himſelf a little; 'tis to be hoped before morning, the Cuffs brisk thoughts of wenching may be pretty well over—Now I will go ſtrike up a merry bargain with Mr Prim as ſoon as he pleaſes: and as I have already taken poſſeſſion of the Breeches, ſo to his ſweet comfort, ſhall he find, that I will make bold to wear 'em ſtoutly, that I will.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: If I ſhould agree to the propoſals you make me, Mr Nickycrack, I fear upon the leaſt diſſatisfaction betwixt us, you would be very apt to fling in my Diſh, a ſpice of my former practices.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ah, no, no, not in the leaſt, Mrs Minx—Come, pray let's be brief in the matter. You have now a pretty Income, for which you may pleaſe to remember, that I have been in ſome meaſure ſerviceable to you. I my ſelf am not without a reaſonable ſtock of Ready, with which I don't doubt but I ſhall riggle my ſelf into ſome employ or other. And we will live ſo ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: And pray what employ do you think would beſt ſuit with your Genius?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: My Genins, indeed, will require ſome very honeſt employ. VVhat think you of a Tax-Collector, a Military Pay Maſter, a Change-Broaker, or a Sollicitor in Parliament?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: A parcel of very conſciencious Callings, truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: (bawling out within.) Ho—lo Minx, why what the Devil at't a doing, and who is that thou haſt got with thee?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hark! Some body calls out, let's go ſee who it is?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: I proteſt 'tis Sir Wealthy Plainder, by all means let's unlooſe him. (They go into the Arbour and lead out Sir VVealthy with his hands bound) VVhy what is the matter Sir Wealthy, in the name of wonder what have they done to ye?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Prithee leave fooling at this rate, give me but my Breeches again and all ſhall be well, faith Child. Then Minky, we'll go into thy Chamber, and there we will fairly unrip 'em. Every tenth piece ſhall be thy own freely, and for each piece I'll have a tubbers at bowls in a Summers day. Ta Doll, di, da, doll, di, da, doll.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Ha! Now I ſmoke the buſineſs. Ha, ha, ha, he's uncas'd I find. He may Ta doll, di, da, doll long enough before Doll will refund again, I'll warrant her. [aſide] Sir Wealthy, I can't imagin what you'd be at. Mr Nickycrack and I are but juſt come into the Garden, and how you come tied after this manner, and what you have had done to ye, I know no more than the man in yonders Moon, not I, I'll promiſe ye.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I profeſs Sir Wealthy I don't know what to think of your Ta, doll, di, da, doll; for my part I'm afraid your Worſhip is at preſent ſomething Lunatick.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Why, what a pox! wou'd you both perſwade me out of my Chriſtian name? Had not I a Letter from you, Mrs. Minx, to meet you here in the Garden? and accordingly I came. You beckon'd, and call'd me into this Arbour, tyed my hands for me, and then run away with my Breeches.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Not one ſyllable of this is truth, by jenkins; now you make a body ſwear.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: In ſhort, Sir Wealthy, you are either diſturb'd in your brain, or have been moſt horribly abus'd; for, upon my ſalvation, this Lady and I have been together for this half hour, and were but juſt come into the Garden as you call'd out.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord! ſuch doings as theſe wou'd make my Brains burſt about my Ears, tho my Scull were ho • p'd with Steel. May the Gods ſend I find all ſafe under the Bench. (Looks under the Bench, then flings it down in a rage) Hell, Furies, Blood, Fire, Death, Deſtruction; and what is worſt of all, Woman, Woman, Woman. I run, I burn, I fly; I'm here, I'm there. I'm ev'ry where, I'm no where, nor never will be any where again.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Why, what is the Devil in Sir Wealthy?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: I believe Legion himſelf has poſſeſt him: He ſeems at preſent even too mad for Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Had I but a grant of his body, I'd cage him up e'faith, and ſhew him about the Country for the Wild Man.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: You had beſt prevail with my Lord Courtipoll, to beg him for you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ay that would be wiſe work indeed, to ſet on a Fool to beg a Madman.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Prithee Mr Nickycrack, let's go in and examin Doll about this buſineſs, I believe ſhe's able to unravel the whole matter.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Madam, if you think convenient, I • d rather be for tying a knot of our own, than unravelling fifty of other peoples.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p:
Why look ye, Mr Nickycrack, I hope you'll give me half an hours time to conſider of your propoſals. I am not unthoughtful of your former favours. And can at preſent aſſure ye, that I hate to be ungrateful. But what requires the moſt expedition is my Siſte •
Thoroſhift's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Madam, I've employ'd Mr. Plodder, my chief Implement of Intelligence, and expect his return every minute. I am confident that by his means I ſhall know the value of the Merchants ſtock; and of the ſubſtance of the Souldiers preferment to a ſingle grain.

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Well, when that's effected then the Parſon goes to work, and Marriage you know is a fruit, that like Nuts generally grows in cluſters.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And egad as ſoon as the Bough is ſhak • d, I • ll be ready with my open arms to take into my boſom the dear ſweet Nut that falls to my ſhare▪

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: That you may, Mr Nickycrack, and get at the Kernel without endangering your Teeth by cracking the ſhell.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Phoo! pox of cracking of ſhells, what care I for cracking of ſhells.

div.l: Who moſt depends upon a Maidenhead,
Is at the beſt, but by a Phantom led.
div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V.
Scene A Room in the Houſe.
div.stage: Sir Bellamour Blunt with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: (Reads.) SIr, conſidering the uſage I meet withal from the moſt unnatural of Parents, and being in ſome meaſure acquainted with the honourable character you maintain in the world, I have at length reſolv'd to confide in your pretenſions, and commit my ſelf wholly into your cuſtody, not doubting but I ſhall meet with a reception worthy your ſelf, and ſuitable to the preſent exigencies of your diſtreſs'd Refugee, Ophelia
At the end of the Gallery leading to the Backſtairs when the clock ſtrikes one.

Oh happy Summons! This is the place, and I am confident it draws near the time. (The Clock ſtrikes) There goes the bleſſed ſtroke, from this minute I'll date my account of bliſs, which may be Gods multiply till the ſumm equals the extent of my paſſion.

div.stage: Enter Widow Thoroſhift Maskt, Captain Bownceby, and Broakage, watching her at two ſeveral doors.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: (Running to her and embracing her) Ophelia! I am not able to ſay more. But—

div.stage: Enter Captain Bownceby at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hell and Hand-granades! I have watched to fine purpoſe, to be at length an eye witneſs of the loſs of my Miſtreſs—No, I ll firſt be ramm'd into the mouth of a Cannon, and be diſcharged againſt my Enemy, with my heels foremoſt, to kick the breath out of his Stomach. (Goes up to Sir Bellamour.) Who are you, Sir, that dare ſhew this familiarity with a Lady to whom Captain Bownceby make pretenſions. If you think fit, Sir, to diſpute my Title, you ſhall find it writ in legible Characters upon this invincible Bilboa Blade. (Draws his Sword, retires to ſome diſtance and flouriſhes it.) Do ye ſee, do ye ſee, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: If you'll walk a little nearer, Sir, you ſhall ſee me break your Bilboa Blade about the ears of you, and imprint its Characters upon your Skull; I am confident 'tis ſoft enough to take the impreſſion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha! A rough Dog! I fear this: what a damn'd ſowre look he has?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Gad I ll venture out. Captain I ſee you are like to be engaged, and tho we are Rivals as to the Widow yonder, yet, with your leave, we will joyn our Forces againſt the common Enemy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With all my heart, honeſt Broakage. Come, prithee do thee march in the Front, and let me bring up the Rear. By my experience in War I'll undertake to make good the Retreat, ſhould we chance to be over-preſs'd.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: No, pray Captain do you take the honour of leading, becauſe you know how to give the Onſet with advantage.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr Broakage.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Nay, dear Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I proteſt you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: I vow it muſt be you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What if we firſt parley, and make our demands in form, and upon refuſal, then fall on?

sp.speaker: Bro
sp.p: Do ſo, Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir, will you ſurrender the VVidow, or not?

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Pray, Madam Ophelia let me beg of you to withdraw for a moment, whilſt I correct the inſolence of theſe two Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Capt
sp.p: Death and Thunderbolts! 'tis none of Ophelia, 'tis the Widow Thoroſhift.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Odſniggers, Sir, 'tis the VVidow Thoroſhift; do but look, and if it does not prove ſo, we'll be content you ſhall bear her off; and we our ſelves will attend your Triumph in chains.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: (looking earneſtly upon the Widow.) Ha! am I impos'd upon? ſince 'tis ſo, Gentlemen, pray take the Lady, I will ſurrender before you draw down your Artillery. I muſt confeſs I look upon the Fort ſo battered, that its not worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Am I not only diſcovered, but affronted with a ſecond contempt? Villain I will have thy blood.

sp.speaker: Capt. and Broa.
sp.p: (laying hold on her.) Patience, patience, good Lady.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Looſe me, ye Poltroons ye. Had either of you the reſpect for me
you pretend to have, or the leaſt dram of Courage, you would a ſter him, and cut his Throat this moment.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Captain, Captain, you underſtand the buſineſs, prithee after him, and fet •• back his head to expiate for his ſawcy crime.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Brimſtone and Blunderbuſs Bullets, Madam, had I thought it manners to have done it before you, I'd have whipt it off before he had ſtirred a ſtep. But if your Ladyſhip pleaſes to lay me any night in Ambuſcade under his Bed, if I leave him an inch of neck to tie his Cravat upon in the morning, may I end my days under a Hedge, and have my Eyes cloſed with Caterpillars.

sp.speaker: Broa.
sp.p: And after that, Madam, if ever he troubles your Ladyſhip more, I'll undertake to decoy him aboard a Ship, and ſo Spirit him away to one of my Plantations.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gentlemen, now my paſſion is ſomething over, I am ready to acknowledge that I am equally oblig'd to both of you, for thus eſpouſing my Quarrel.—'Tis a miſerable caſe that I am forc'd to keep my ſelf on fair terms with ſuch a couple of ninny Lovers as theſe. (aſide) Gentlemen, I am now going to ſee truſty Nibs married. She has got one of our Modern-Play Lovers, that lies in wait for her, and yet knows nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And then, Madam.

sp.speaker: Broa.
sp.p: And then, Madam.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You are very civil, Mr. Broakage, thus to take out of one ear what I whiſper'd into the other.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No jarring, Gentlemen, on penalty of my eternal diſpleaſure. As ſoon as Nibs is married, we'll get together, and dance till morning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Captain Bownceby ſhall be ready to attend your Ladyſhip, with evry Caper five foot high.

sp.speaker: Broa.
sp.p: And your obedient Slave, Mr. Broakage, ſhall Coupee and Coulee to your Ladyſhip, as dextrouſly as a Beau does to himſelf at the great Glaſs in the Chocolate-houſe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Theſe Beaus have a fine time on't, when ſuch Blockheads as thee muſt have a fling at 'em. (aſide.) Gentlemen, I am your ſervant

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now, Sir, the common danger is over, what if we about again as we were?

sp.speaker: Broa.
sp.p: You are in the right, I proteſt, Captain; but firſt let's embrace. Your Servant, noble Captain. Exeunt. Capt Your Servant, ſweet Mr Broakage—Now mind to turn ſhort upon your left heel at the word of command. To the right about • march.

div.stage: [They face about at the ſame time and march off Enter Ld Courtipoll, Vainthroat, and Sweetny.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: I vow I am glad to ſee your noble Lordſhip ſafe returned; how generouſly it was done, thus to expoſe your precious perſon for all our ſafeties.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: As it happened there was no danger, the buſineſs only proved a Match at Foot-ball in Moor-Fields, but I have been ſo plagued with the inſolence of onſtables, not one of the Scoundrels would kn • w me to be a man of quality; but after abundance of barbarous uſage, I was hurried before a City Magiſtrate, who at firſt very haſtily ſent word, that we • e I the beſt m • n in the Kingdom I muſt be ſecured till morning. But at length upon much ſollicitation, he and his wife examined the buſineſs, and upon her command I was ſet at liberty Upon my honour ſhe was a very prett • woman, and took occaſion to draw up her Breaſts, mump her Mouth, and ſay, ſhe believed I was a perſon of quality by my white Hand and diamond •• ng.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: O goodneſs! ſure every body may know that by your graceful deportment.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: It is fifty to one, my Lord, but you'll have her at Court e're long a ſolliciting Knighthood for her Husband, and then—

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Then I'll take care ſhe ſhall ſucceed e'faith. And when the beaſt of her Husband has his ſhoulders loaded with a Sirdom, it ſhall be my buſineſs to give the addition of a corniferous badge, and adorn his front with a courtly Cuckoldom—But Mrs Sweetny, where is Ophelia?

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Alas poor young Lady, ſhe's very dutifully attending upon her Father—Sir Wealthy, my Lord, is of a ſudden run quite beſides himſelf. See where ſhe comes along with him.

div.stage: Enter Sir Wealthy Plainder very melancholy, attended by Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Will you be pleaſed, Sir, to take a little repoſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: No, Child, luſt and villany never ſleep.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Good lack, what is to be done with him, ſee how ſtrangely thoughtful he looks.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Be gone, Ophelia, there's a cup of Poyſon by you, nay, the deadly draught was prepar'd by thy Fathers own hand; be gone I ſay.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: This ſudden care of me is wondrous ſtrange; by this my Father rather ſeems to have recovered than loſt his ſences. (aſide) I • ll go try what account I can get of the occaſion of all this.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Why how now old fellow, what art run mad?

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Yes, young Coxcomb, I am mad.

sp.speaker: Vain
sp.p: Then here's one ſhall match thee faith. (aſide.) My Lord, a perſon of your univerſal knowledge, may find out the nature of this Gentlemans diſtemper, and by that means a recovery may be thought on.

sp.speaker: Ld Cour.
sp.p: Ha? let's ſee what's to he done with him; why if the Gentlemas Noddle has ſprung a Leak, the beſt way will be to ply the pumps. Mr Vainthroat, do you take the other arm, and I will manage this, and let's work him a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: (flying from 'em) Looſe me, thou fantaſtick Vanity, thou finiſht folly.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: You are very familiar with your betters, methinks good Mr Mad man.

sp.speaker: Sweet.
sp.p: Its a ſign indeed the poor Gentlemans diſtraction is very great, he could never have thought that your Lordſhip could poſſibly have been a fool elſe.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Let us conſider Mr. Vainthroat—By what I can apprehend of him he only affects a ſurly humour, and under the pretence of madneſs takes the liberty of being ſawcy; prithee let us laugh him out on • t.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Lord, ſay what you will, I will have a laugh at your ſervice—I think I may ſafely promiſe that, for the Coxcomb is ſcarce capable of ſaying any thing but what is very ridiculous, and yet has the vanity to think a man laughs at the gayety of his parts.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what, Sir Wealthy has my quondam Miſtreſs put thee thus in the dumps. Its a ſign thou wert a Madman to venture coming after a man of my quality—Mr Vainthroat.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: My Lord. Oh—ha, ha, ha. S'bud I'd forgot to laugh at the right ſtop.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p:
Come Knight, prithee cheer up Man, I'll make thy poſterity
amends for thy misfortunes, I'll infuſe into Ophelia, ſuch a ſtream of ſenſe and ſolidity, that ſhe ſhall become the mother of a Generation diſtinguiſht by the name of the Matchiavellian Courtipollions.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, there I was ready for you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal
sp.p: And I am as ready to deſpiſe both your impertinences.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: I find nothing will move the ſullen Sot, prithee for Ophelia's ſake, ſee him ſafe to his Chamber, while Mrs Sweetny and I go and puſh on my affairs with the Virgin that I have now upon my hands

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Like a man of your quality

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O Sir Wealthy, I was looking for you. Pray don't give way to this ſtrange ſort of ſplenatick humour; do but walk in, and you'll ſoon find how matters ſtand.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: What care I how matters ſtand, I could now, with a ſteddy unconcern, ſee the crazy props of Nature ſlip their hold, and all this giddy world ſtagger into eternal Confuſion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ha! what is the old Rogue turned Stoick?

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Faith I can▪t tell what to make of him, not I—But Nickycrack I am in expectation of flinging of Stockings, and lapping of Sack-poſſets, and ſo forth. Is there any thing to be done to night or not?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes faith, there will be tickling work anon; you ſhall ſee me take my turn too.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: E'gad it ſhall go very hard but I'll have ſome tickling amongſt ye. Bite of the Bridle as ſoon as you will, I'll take my turn in the Saddle I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: See here comes one couple already; the finical Mr Prim has very nicely eſpouſed honeſt Country Doll.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Joy to thee Doll. What has the Court then ſtruck a laſting Covenant with the Country?

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: Yes indeed, poor Doll here has at length been bribed to betray herſelf into the bonds of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, no more plain Doll, I beſeech you, I am confident ſhe can now lay a juſt claim to the title of Madam Prim, and I hope that term won't in the leaſt damnify your voices in the expreſſion, Gentlemen; prithee my dear, mind my way of talking, you muſt now ſtrive to leave off your Country Dialect, and give to every word you ſpeak, a pretty gentile courtly twang

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here's Mrs Nibs, I dare ſay is married too, by the ſolemn paw ſhe takes, and by that pretty bluſh which ſhe cunningly aſſumes, to bid a formal adieu to what ſhe has long parted withal. Is it not ſo, Mrs Nibs?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Yes indeed, I am faſt enough; but what's the jeſt, is, the man that has married me, knows not a ſyllable of the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: If half the Husbands in the Kingdom were to be kept in the ſame ignorance, • my Conſcience they'd have reaſon enough to think themſelves happy fellows. Were I to adviſe you, I▪d never let him know it, leſt he ſhould repent his bargain, ha forſooth?

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Pray, Mr Vainthroat, for the future, vouchſafe to let your Forſooths be Madams when you ſpeak to me, for I aſſure you I have married a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You won't pretend to take place of Madam Prim I hope.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Madam Prim! Ha, ha, ha, that's a good one e'faith.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, why this publick deriſion of a perſon that has married a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: A Gentleman, ha, ha, ha. Had my Husband no better a pretence to his gentility, I ſhould bluſh to hear my ſelf Madam'd. If you will give me leave, I can give you an exact account of your pedigree.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: By all means let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Well, then, I dont love to ſay much, but what I do ſay ſhall be to the purpoſe. Jacob Scout, the Beadle of Cripplegate Pariſh, will be ready at any time to juſtify upon Oath what I am going to ſay. You muſt know then, that this very Gentleman who pretends himſelf of Prim Caſtle in the borders of Scotland, was not many years ſince a ſquauling bantling, laid in a Hand-basket upon a Bulk in Woodſtreet, and being taken care of by the Pariſh, old Scout the Beadle was his Godfather, and afterwards—

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: You're a baſe Detractor of my Honor, and I'll have you—

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Nay, hold, hold, let's hear the full charge before you make your reply, good Mr Prim.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: Afterwards I ſay, this Gentleman Mr Prim, when he was grown a little up, was put in among the Blue-coat Boys, and my Lord Courtipoll being one day a viſiting Chriſt's-Hoſpital, his Lordſhip diſcovering ſomething in the youths face that promis'd a future dexterity in the ſubtle vocation of pimping, he was pleaſed to entertain him in his ſervice, where he has continued ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: O dem her diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Vain. and Nick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: E'faith Nibs, if I ben't even with you for thus publickly expoſing Mr Prim, I'll be bound to forfeit all the famous qualifications of my Sex, and be a ſcandalous Apoſtate to the whole race of Womankind.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Nay, not ſo, pray child, that would be the way to baulk the Devil of his due, and it is pity he ſhould be wrong'd of one ſingle Member of the Sex.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I find Mr Prim, your Lady does not require much inſtruction in her ſpeech: methinks her Dialect is very courtly of a ſudden.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: No, nor in any thing elſe relating to the Town, I'll paſs my word for't. I dare ſay Madam Prim here, knows as much of aſſignation, ſnapping, faſtning, looſening, and counterfetching, with all the numerous turns of Jilting and Coquetry, as well as ever a Hackney Coach-plyer, Pit-padder, or Gallery-galloper about the Town of London.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Death! is it ſo too?

sp.speaker: Nick. and Vain.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The danger is over, the danger is over; Ta, doll, di, da, da, ra.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: How came you empty handed then? where's the Bride?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: She's ſafe enough boy, you ſhall ſee her betwixt a pair of Sheets with me preſently, and if you lie near me, you ſhall hear me a thundering it away, a hammering out of young Hercules's, ye dog you.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Gad they'll be very wooden ones if they're like their Father.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But if you have got the Widow, Captain, pray what have you done with the Merchant?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ah poor Broakage, I cannot imagin what will become of the puppy, it's fifty to one but he has already knotted his Garters, and is gaping about for ſome convenient nooſing place or other.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here he comes e'faith, as merry as your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Now, now the Fight is done; Ta, di, doll, da, ra, da. The Widow • s mine own, faith boys. Now, Mr Captain, you may march about your buſineſs as ſoon as you pleaſe, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why what • s the fellow diſtracted, ye Nehemian Ninnyhammer you, I ſay I have married the Widow.

sp.speaker: Bro
sp.p: Why ye Belzebubbian Blunderbus ye, I ſay I have married the Widow▪

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are both very confident of the matter, methinks, be it how it will, it is time for me to look after my own Match: but to prevent diſputes in my caſe, you ſhall ſee me enter with my Bride in my hand I • ll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: No quarrelling, pray Gentlemen, ſince you have both married the Widow, why ſhould you fall out about the matter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What ſayſt thou, Jeronimo? Peace or War, the Olive branch or the Bilboa Blade?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Why faith Captain, let's have a Truce at the leaſt, ſince we have both courted her in amity, and married her in amity, e' • e let us both keep her in amity—Here comes the Lady, pray let her decide the buſineſs.

div.stage: Enter Widow Thoroſhift. A Table and Candles.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Madam, here is a great Controverſie, which of theſe two Gentlemen does your Ladyſhip deſign to own for a Husband?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: To deal plainly with you, it's ſcarce in my power to tell; they were both ſo urgent for privacy, that having neither light to diſcern, nor ſpeaking loud enough to diſtinguiſh a voice, all that I know is, that a Husband I have; but which of theſe two Gentlemen 'tis—

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: 'Tis me, by Jerico.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By Jerico, ye ſneaking Whores-bird. Tis me by. Jove, Madam, and all the reſt of the thundring powers above.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That will ſoon be decided by the contents of this little Ceremonial Implement.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Pray then let that little Ceremonial Implement, as you call it, clear this matter in diſpute.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It ſhall ſo, Sir, I'll read the Motto, then let the Gentleman from whoſe hands I reeeiv • d it, claim me for his own lawful Spouſe till death does us part. (Reads.) The Widow's my own, Fleſh, Blood, and Bone.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: E'gad ſo ſhe is, and accordingly I'll take poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why what the Devil then 〈◊〉 of mine, ha?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: That, good Captain, you ſhall know preſently. Nibs, read the poeſy of your Ring.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p: (Reads) I ſwear by my Courage, I'll rummage your Stowage.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hell, Blood, and Furies, thy Stowage! why what a pox ſhall I get by that, ha?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nibs.
sp.p:
Your Servant, ſweet Captain, indeed you promis'd I ſhould be a Captains Lady, but I did not think you were ſo kind to deſign me for your ſelf, good Captain—Come, Sir, don't be diſcouraged, I • ll undertake to
do thoſe good offices for you with your General, that ſhall make you bownce forward in preferment at a ſtrange rate.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Like enough, faith Nibs, your bowncing in the buſineſs may do much. A nights ſervice for a General in the Trenches, will do more for the Captain • s advancement, than his own ſervice in Siege Trenches all his life time▪ But here comes a couple hand in hand that ha • e made ſure work. [Enter Nickycrack leading Minx] And here comes ano •• er couple, tho the Lady at preſent ſeems to carry it a little too ſhy for a Wife

div.stage: Enter Ophelia, followed by Sir Bellamour with a Trunk.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: I have • old you, Madam, how I came to diſcover it, and knowing what uſage you have met withal, I did believe my ſelf bound in juſtice to ſecure it. Here tis for you, (Gives her the Trunk.) Its value I know not. If you think my concern for your Intereſt merits a good eſteem for you, I ſhall look upon my ſelf over-paid.

sp.speaker: Oph
sp.p: I am not, Sir, to be brib'd into an eſteem; but here comes my Father, to whom I ſuppoſe it may properly belong, I ſhall therefore take care to reſtore it.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Here is ſomething, Sir, which this Gentleman, Sir Bellamour Blunt, would willingly f • rce upon me, knowing that 'tis my duty to acquaint you with what offers are made me, I humbly remit it into your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: (Taking the Trunk) Ha! is it ſo? Well Child, this I ſhall take care on, and if you think good to make the Gentleman any acknowledgement for his piece of ſervice, pray do it with your perſon, if Sir Bellamour will accept of you without the Casket.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Moſt willingly, Sir Wealthy.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p: Then I muſt bluſhing own, that my inclinations ſuits with my Fathers commands; and my only regret is, that ſo deſerving a Gentleman as I believe Sir Bellamour to be, ſhould meet with ſo poor a bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Bell.
sp.p: Madam, I love you, and the poſſeſſing the object belov'd, is, I think, the greateſt treaſure that this world affords.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Here's ſtrange coupling, my Lord, of a ſudden; your Virgin too has given you the ſlip, e'faith, and tho not Parſon-fetter'd, yet ſhe ha • fairly ſurrenderd herſelf in order to it.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Ay! ſay you ſo? then it muſt be ſo.

div.stage: Knocking without, Doll goes off, and immediately returns with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Here's a Letter directed to Mr Nickycrack, to be delivered with all the ſpeed imaginable.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: I gueſs from whence it comes; but be the Contents what they will it comes too late for prevention. (Looking in the Letter.) O miſerable, miſerable news I proteſt! for my part I han't power to read it.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: (Taking the Letter.) Let me ſee it, I • ll read it read it out contain what it will. (Reads, Sir, as ſoon as poſſibly I could get my full intelligence I have ſent you this, to give you an account, that Captain Bownceby, as you call him, is no Captain, but a bluſtering Subaltern Officer that was caſheer • d for • owardice

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Blood and Fire-balls! Furies and Fugacies.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, alas poor Nibs! you are a Captains Lady, forſooth, and have married a man of Honour, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p:
But to proceed (Reads.) As for Mr Broakage, he is no Merchant, but has been employed by the Jews to drive ſome rooking bargains upon the
Change, where he is at preſent ſo far out of Credit, that is apprehended, I believe his ears muſt attone for his former practices.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: A curſe upon his Plodſhip!

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Why what out of countenance, Mr Broakage, why it is but moving into one of your foreign Plantations man, hah?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come chear up, Mr Broakage, to tell ye truth my circumſtances are as bad as yours can be, and ſince we have trickt one another, there's no remedy now, but to reſt ſatisfied, and lay our heads together, how we may ſham old Creditors, collogue in with new ones, make a • earing figure, and ſo trick all the world beſides

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I hope, my Lord, I have no ways incurr'd your Lordſhips diſpleaſure, by taking poſſeſſion of a Relict of your Lordſhips.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: What my Country Pug married, ha?

sp.speaker: Minx.
sp.p: Your Country Pug knows as much of the Town as another body; and tho by my Country pretenſions, I have made ſhift to •• ll your Lordſhip out of a Settlement, yet I do not queſtion but I ſhall make as juſt a Wife to Mr Nickycrack here, as any ſits at my Lady Mayoreſs • s Table, at a Lord Mayors Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: That I believe you may, Madam, and hold on dealing with the Court into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Ha! ſince you are ſo pert, Mrs Minx, I can ſatisfie you that your Settlement is not worth one farthing, it's drawn upon an Eſtate that I can make no Title to.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O fie! I hope not ſo, my Lord, that can never be acted like a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: But it can be acted like a State • man tho, and that's my pretenſions, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Weal.
sp.p: Now good people, give a Mad man leave to ſpeak: I have at length obſerved, that for the procuring of this Devil of Wealth we ſtick at no Baſeneſs, and the poſſeſſing it does generally ſerve to foment our Villanies. I will therefore before all theſe witneſſes voluntarily part with my greateſt ſtore, and put it into the hands of a Gentleman, that if I miſtake not, is Maſter of ſuch vertuous inclinations, that will direct him in the right uſe of it. Here, Sir Bellamour, (Gives him the Trunk) let what's in here ſerve to guild Matrimony, and make the bitter doſe of woman go down the better.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Then Joy to my old friend, Sir Bellamour Blunt, and to his beautiful Ophelia. If there can be ſuch a thing as Felicity in a married ſtate, it muſt certainly be found in ſuch a well match'd pair as theſe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As far as I find, here is every body well match'd.

sp.speaker: Ld Court.
sp.p: Come then, let us grace theſe ſolemnities with a Dance: but the next Virginity Game I undertake, ſhall be play'd with more politick Caution, I'll pawn my Honour for't.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, let each man to bed with his own Wife.
sp.l: May branded ſeem, for being old offenders,
In feats of Love let none be bare pretenders.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: THE writing Plays, a ſort of Lott'ry is,
There's many Blanks for one good lucky Prize.
Our Author hopes he has your humour hit,
And now by me his Proxy does ſubmit
To own this placethe Judgment-ſeat of Wit.
But does avow no Criticks vote is good;
Butchers are ne're return'd in caſe of Blood
Whoe're for Juſtice does on them rely,
Does the ſame thing as Councel with a Spy.
Let each free ſoul, his proper Verdict tell,
And pin no faith on Critick Infidel.
'Twas your applauſe firſt drew the Poet in;
Won't you then ſpare whom y • u intic'd to 〈◊〉 ?
In comick Socks ſtill let him trip 〈◊〉 Stage,
And ſtigmatize the follies of the age.
Till by your ſmiles he has ſuch vigour won,
May make him dare to draw the Buskin on.
High in expence who ud not his utmoſt do,
When he's to treat ſuch gallant Gueſts as you?
You are the worſt of foes, but beſt of friends.
Let ranting Coxcombs ſcorn an Audience fro •• ,
He only writes, who writes to pleaſe the Town.
